What's your most embarrassing prom night story? Senior year, I finally worked up the courage to ask my crush Ebony to prom. She said yes, and I was convinced this would be the perfect night to tell her how I felt about her. I spent weeks planning everything. Rented a tux, spot a corsage, even practiced my I've liked you since freshman year speech in the mirror. The one thing I insisted on was driving. My friends all wanted to split an Uber, but I had this romantic vision of picking Ebony up in my car, just the two of us having deep conversations on the way there. What I didn't mention was that my car was a 2003 Toyota Camry with a dent in the side and a muffler that sounded like a dying whale. Ebony looked absolutely stunning when I picked her up. She was wearing this gorgeous blue dress, and I was so nervous I could barely speak. The drive to prom was going perfectly. We were talking, laughing, and I was building up the courage to tell her how I felt at prom. Everything was magical. We dance, I danced, took pictures, and I was planning to confess my feelings during the slow songs. But then my friends Jake and Marcus found me around ten PM, completely wasted from pre gaming in the parking lot. Dude, Jake slurred, hanging all over me. We need a ride home right now. Marcus threw up on his date shoes. And we got kicked out of the after party. I tried I to explain that I was having a moment with Ebony, but Marcus was turning green and mumbling about needing to get home before his parents found out he was drunk. Ebony, being the sweet person she is, said, it's okay. We should help them. We can talk later. So there I was, loading two drunk idiots into my Toyota while wearing a 200 dollar tuxedo. Jake immediately claimed shotgun and started messing with my radio while Marcus sprawled across the back seat groaning about his stomach. This car smells weird! Announced loudly, like old French fries and sadness. Ebony squeezed into the back seat next to Marcus, who kept apologizing for ruining prom night while simultaneously asking if we had any snacks. I was driving extra carefully because I had precious cargo, but Jake kept grabbing the steering wheel, saying, dude, you're driving like my grandma. Speed up! Then Marcus suddenly sat up and yelled, pull over! I'm gonna be sick! I swerved to the side of the road so fast that my muffler backfired like a gunshot. Marcus jumped out and started throwing up in someone's front yard while Jake cheered him on like it was a sporting event. That's when the police car pulled up behind us with its lights flashing. Officer Johnson got out, and of course it was the same cop who'd given me a speeding ticket last month. He took one look at Me in my tuxedo, my Toyota with the hood smoking slightly, and two drunk teenagers in formal wear. And just shook his head. Well, well, well, what do we have here? I tried to explain that I was the designated driver, completely sober, just helping my friends, but Jake chose that moment to stumble over and loudly declare,

What happened when my parents blamed me for my brother's chaos? When I turned 18, my parents sat me down for what they called a long overdue conversation. You need to move out, mom announced. Every disaster in this house happens because you're constantly provoking Gonzales. I stared in disbelief while my 14 year old brother Gonzales sat there looking innocent. The kitchen fire last week, the destroyed laptop, the hole in the garage door. It's always when you two are together. We need peace. You have two weeks to find somewhere else to live, Gonzalez smiled sweetly. I just want our family to be safe, he said, hiding behind my parents backs as he mouthed goodbye. Fine. If they wanted me to stop protecting them from Hurricane Gonzalez, I'd wish them good luck. The day after I moved out, Gonzalez decided to upgrade the house's electrical system. Every light in the neighborhood now flickered in rhythm with our toaster when mom tried to make toast. It activated the garage door, the ceiling fans and somehow started Dad's car. The power company had to shut down our entire grid and rewire our house. Bill was $3,000. It's synchronized living, Gonzales explained proudly to the electrician. Next he discovered online chemistry tutorials without me secretly replacing his chemicals with baking soda, he created what he called rainbow smoke bombs in the kitchen. But they were actually just straight up acid that ate through the tiles and corrupted all the food. Hazmat Had to gut our kitchen entirely. Total cost, $8,000. Why didn't you tell us this would happen? Mom yelled at me through the phone. I did. You just never listened, I reminded her. Then Gonzales revealed he'd been training squirrels in the attic. They're my army, he explained, as 20 squirrels wearing tiny tin foil hats and it through the ceiling during Dad's Zoom meeting with his boss. Dad got fired on the spot. Then came the car improvement incident. Gonzalez filled Dad's gas tank with what he called super juice, a mixture of energy drinks, lighter fluid and glitter. The car made it exactly.

What's the fastest you've seen a harmless joke turn fatal? I'll never forget seeing the new kid, Ben, sitting alone at his desk at Tuesday morning, tears streaming down his face, while the entire their class erupted in laughter around him. He was almost completely deaf and had been an easy target every single day since he transferred to our school. A few guys stood behind him, their mouths moving in exaggerated yells that Ben couldn't hear. Making obscene gestures and mimic king sign language, while Ben just saw everyone laughing at him and pointing. Gabe would take it to the next level, as he'd go as far as to scream right behind him, knowing he wouldn't react. The math teacher had stepped out to make copies, and in those five minutes, they'd already reduced Ben to tears. His eyes darted around the room, desperately trying to understand what was so funny, what he'd done wrong this time. But he just couldn't understand. I tried to help him, but every attempt just made things worse for both of us. When I stood up and told them to stop in lunch last week, he just laughed and said I had a crush on the stupid deaf kid. Which became another joke that followed me through the halls. At least three or four incidents every single day, always when teachers weren't looking. Always calculated to make Ben feel the biggest loser in our whole school. I reported it to the principal twice. But she just said, boys will be boys, and that Ben needed to learn to stand up for himself. How could he stand up to harassment he couldn't even hear? Gabe was a literal monster, but I had no idea how far he was about to go. I made one last attempt to handle this the right way by going directly to the guidance counselor with my documented evidence. I showed him three weeks of detailed notes explaining how the bullying was escalating, how Ben had started eating lunch in the bathroom, how his grades were dropping because he was too anxious to focus in class. I told her all about how Gabe had been harassing him daily, making his life a living hell. She looked at my notebook side and said that I should focus on my own education. I thought she was joking at first, but then I realized the guidance counselor was friends with Gabe's mom, and I knew she didn't believe any of it. Ben needs to learn to communicate better with his peers. Communicate better? How the hell was he supposed to communicate with people he couldn't even hear? I was about to say that, but then a loud ringing sound went off in my ear. The fire alarm started blaring right next to me, and everyone filed out in the usual chaos of an unexpected drill. I was already outside when I noticed those same guys huddled together, laughing nervously but trying to play It cool. They were talking about something, but I had too much on my mind to listen. The building was actually smoking. I'd never seen this before, because this wasn't actually a drill. We all stood outside watching it. When I heard one of them say, yo, we should probably tell someone now. I was listening. Gabe told them to be quiet, but another guy said, guys, we can't just leave him there. That fire is huge. I knew who him was immediately. I asked what they meant. Gabe had tears in his eyes. Ben still in there? We left him as a joke because he couldn't hear the alarm. The building was now engulfed in flames, windows shattering from the heat.

While I delivered a baby, the mother asked, where's your nearest trash can? Why, it's in the corner of your room. I gestured toward the small medical waste bin while cradling the Newborn, who was struggling to breathe. Go ahead and toss it for me, please. She said it so casually, like she was asking me to throw away a tissue. What? Ma'am, this is your baby. I held the infant closer to my chest protectively. Look at it. The little turd is hardly alive. He can barely breathe. Just do us all a favor and throw it out. Her pupils were dilated and she kept scratching at her arms. Absolute not. I turned away from her and started checking the baby's vitals. I'd seen the track marks on her arms during delivery. The baby was born premature and underweight, with clear signs of neonatal abstinence syndrome. His little body was already going through withdrawal from whatever substances his mother had been using during pregnancy. He needed immediate medical intervention, not a trash can. The mother started getting agitated when I didn't comply. She sat up in the bed, despite having just given birth 20 minutes ago. Her hospital gown was soaked with sweat and blood, but she didn't seem to notice or care. The way she looked at her own child like he was garbage made my stomach turn. I knew I had to get this baby to the NICU immediately. His breathing was shallow and his skin had A bluish tint that worried me. Every second counted. But I also couldn't just walk out without following protocol. I needed to document everything and alert social services about the mother's request to dispose of her child. I'm going to take your son for treatment now. He needs oxygen and monitoring. I kept my voice calm and professional. The mother's eyes narrowed. She looked around the room like she was calculating something. Then her whole demeanor changed. Her face contorted into fake panic, and she started screaming at the top of her lungs. Help me! This woman is trying to hurt my baby! Her voice echoed down the hospital corridor. Within seconds, three other doctors rushed into the room. Doctor the Peters and Doctor Burton looked between me and the screaming mother, trying to assess the situation. Behind them, Nurse Melendez appeared, looking concerned. They all knew me, but they also had to respond to a mother's distress call about her Newborn. Put the baby down and return it to the mother. Doctor Peters used his authority voice. No! I'm trying to save this baby's life! She asked me to throw him in the trash can. She's not in a state to care for him. I held the infant tighter. The mother's performance escalated. Tears streamed down her face as she reached toward me with shaking hands. She's insane. Why would anyone want to throw out their baby? I looked desperately at my colleagues. They had to see through this. Act. The baby in my arms was barely breathing and needed immediate care. His mother was clearly high and had just asked me to dispose of him like medical waste. But the other doctors were looking at me strangely. Doctor de Burton stepped closer with his hands up, like he was approaching a dangerous animal. Gabriella, did you take your medication today? When we hired you, you promised to never miss a day of your medication. My heart sank. They thought I was having an episode. Five years ago, I'd had a brief mental health crisis. During my residency, I've been properly diagnosed and treated for bipolar disorder. I've been stable on medication ever since. But that history would always follow me. Now this manipulative woman was using it against me. I never

My family staged an intervention over our McDonald's wedding. So we're three months from the wedding, and I make the mistake of telling my family we finally booked our venue. A big mistake. My mother in law immediately goes into interrogation mode. What's the theme? Is it rustic beach? I say it's a surprise, and she literally follows me to the bathroom door, going, I carried that boy for nine months. I deserve to know if I need waterproof mascara for three weeks. It escalates. My sister in law creates a group chat called Wedding Venue Detectives. My cousin starts checking venue parking lots for our cars. My mother in law accidentally opens our mail claiming she was looking for coupons. My aunt shows up at three different venues with my photo, asking if we have a reservation. The breaking point is this family dinner where my mother in law ambushes us with a laminated list saying, these are all possible venues within 50 miles. Just point. My sister adds, we need to know. I look at my husband, who mouths, just tell them like a broken man. I look at his mother with her Office Depot laminated list. My sister recording for Instagram, my cousin, who's been stalking parking lots. Something in me breaks. You want to know so badly? Fine. I stand up slowly and make eye contact with everyone. We're having our reception at McDonald's. I let that hang for three full seconds, watching their brains buffer Someone drops their fork. The one on Main Street with the Play Place. It goes that's not funny, but I'm stone faced. We already put down the deposit. My husband catches on, immediately nod seriously, the manager, Gary, is really excited. My sister's wine glass shatters on the floor. My mother in law asks about dinner and I go everyone gets Happy Meals, nuggets or Big Mac. No substitutions. My aunt starts crying you cannot feed my friends nuggets at your wedding! Meanwhile, my uncle practically throws his wallet at us asking if it's about money. I do a quick Google and show them someone did this already in 2,015. First dance under the golden arches, I say wistfully. My sister in law shrieks about her two hundred dollar shoes and how they just cannot touch a McDonald's floor. My husband commits fully. Instead of cake, we're doing an apple pie tower. Ronald McDonald is officiating. I add we're registered at McDonald's for gift cards. My mother in law looks at me with pure betrayal. What will Father Michael think when he finds out you're getting married by a clown next morning? My mother in law shows up with menu brochures. This barn is available! I'll pay for everything! I pull out the fake McDonald's catering menu I made at 3:00am. Too late. We customized our Mcflurry Bar. Oreo for my side, M&M for his. She grips the door frame. By day three, my cousin reveals they had an emergency Family meeting and created a Powerpoint to convince my husband and I to call off the McDonald's disaster. They called it Operation Real Venue with Slide 7 titled signs they've lost their Minds. Week two, my aunt calls crying that she can't tell her book club my knee.

What's the most delusional thing someone has said to you with a straight face? My best friend asked me to quit my 180,000 dollar V P. Position to watch her kids because daycare is for people who don't have friends with maternal instincts and she could not miss her wine tasting certification course. Madison told me for years that I was meant to be a stay at home mom and a natural mother while dumping her children at my door every single day. Madison and I met at our first corporate jobs, where we both swore we'd be C E O s by 30. Then I had twins at 28 and everything changed for me overnight, while Madison kept climbing that ladder until she married a cardiac surgeon and retired at 20 9 to live her best life. The morning I told her I was leaving work to raise my kids, she hugged me and whispered, you're going to be such an amazing mother because you actually have those maternal instincts, unlike women like me who need more stimulation. When my husband got laid off and money got tight, she was the first to say staying home was still the right choice since I was so naturally nurturing and some women were just meant to be mothers. By the time my twins were two and I had my third baby, Madison had her first kid with her surgeon husband. Three weeks postpartum, she showed up at my door at six In the morning with her Newborn still covered in spit up, and announced, why would I pay strangers when my best friend is literally the best mother I know? Before I could answer, she was already backing out of my driveway in her new Range Rover, leaving her screaming baby in my arms while texting her personal trainer. Every morning became a hostage situation where Madison would ring my doorbell before dawn with her daughter and whatever emergency made it impossible for her to parent that day, from Pilates to brunches to urgent manicures that couldn't be rescheduled. When I suggested the elite daycare that her husband could definitely afford, she laughed and said, those places are where lazy parents abandon their children. But I have you. Why would I traumatize my baby with strangers? When Madison had her second baby, she didn't even pretend to consider childcare. You're literally glowing when you're surrounded by all these babies while I just feel trapped. So really, I'm doing you a favor by giving you more purpose in life. She dropped both kids with ear infections and stomach bugs while she attended charity luncheons where she'd complain about how exhausting motherhood was to women who actually watched their own children. She sent me midnight texts saying she needed me to take the kids for three days because her husband was at a medical conference and she absolutely had to join him, which I'd later see on Instagram was her at a Miami Spa resort while he worked while she posted champagne selfies. I was managing five kids through stomach flu and when I texted that her son had a fever of 103, she replied with a thumbs up emoji and asked if I could handle the weekend too since she booked a couple's massage. She threw elaborate birthday parties, taking credit for the Pinterest perfect decorations while telling other moms blessed she was to be so hands on even though I was doing everything while she got Botox. For six years, this was my life. While Madison remodeled her third house and posted about the struggles of being a stay at home mom. Her village that made it all possible, as she said in her posts, was literally just me watching her kids for free, including Christmas morning when she flew to Aspen because she desperately needed a break from the holidays. Everything shifted when my youngest started kindergarten and I had seven hours of freedom every weekday for the first time in six years. I updated my resume and started interviewing while Madison acted like I'd personally betrayed her by even suggesting I might want something beyond her childcare.

While filling her cavities, my eight year old patient asked, do grown UPS at your house play the statue game, too? I smiled. I haven't heard of that one. Her words slurred from the laughing gas. It's when I hear daddy's car and everyone freezes like statues. My hygienist, Sierra, raised an eyebrow. That sounds interesting. How do you play? When we hear the garage, Mommy says statue time and we all freeze wherever we are, Isabella explained drowsily. Even if I'm eating or playing, everything stops. That's when I noticed the faint yellow marks on her upper arm, mostly hidden by her sleeve. Sometimes I'm really good at it. Last week I held my spoon in the air for 20 whole minutes. She seemed proud. Mommy said I was the best statue ever. Twenty minutes is a long time, I said, gently adjusting her sleeve to see better. Fingerprint bruises? Old ones. Can you raise your arm for me, sweetie? I need to adjust the chair. As she raised both arms, her shirt rode up. Linear marks crossed her lower back, some scarred, some fresh. What happens if someone moves during statue time? I kept working, acting like I was just doing my job. That's losing. Daddy doesn't like when we lose. Excuse myself to get a different tool, stepping to my computer to pull up our mandatory reporting protocols. When I returned, I asked casually, and if you win the statue game? If we're all good statues, daddy, Walks through and goes to his room. Then we can breathe normal again. Sometimes he even says good job and we get to eat dinner. You get to eat dinner? Only if we win. Losers don't deserve dinner. But mommy sneaks me crackers later. I made a show of checking Isabella's chart while secretly measuring the bruise patterns with my pen light. 3 2 cm spread on the grip marks. Adult male hand size. Isabella, what other games does your family play? I asked oceaning my hygiene to discreetly check on the father. The listening game, where he asks questions and we have to answer exactly right. I pulled out my light open wide again. What kind of questions? Like who's the most important person in this house? The answer is always daddy. The light revealed slight scarring on her inner cheek, likely from biting during stress. Happens when someone gets the answer wrong. Sometimes no breakfast or lunch. My tummy hurts so bad, but crying makes it worse. My least favourite one is the quiet room. I set down my tools. Tell me about this quiet room. While I set up this X ray. I positioned the lead apron, noting how she winced when I touched her shoulders. It's the closet under the stairs. No light. We stay until we're sorry enough. I count to know how long I lasted. My record is 10,000 seconds. What's yours? The excitement in her voice broke my heart. That was over two And a half hours. That's a lot of counting, Sierra returned, mouthing her dad's asking how much longer you'll be. Mommy went in there last week, Isabella continued. He had to fold up real small cause she's bigger. Daddy said she forgot who pays the bills. Sometimes I hear her crying in there, but I can't help or I go in too. We Learned that rule the hard way. I took the X rays, handed her some stickers, and said, I need to develop these. Sierra will stay with you in the hallway. I called CPS from my cell. Active abuse case. Child has physical marks. Describes systematic torture disguised as games. Father is in waiting room. Returning, I pretended to review her chart. Isabella, has anyone else seen you play these games? No, silly. It's a family secret.

My daughter wanted me to be the mom who never punished her, so I became that mom. Amelia threw herself onto her bed, still wearing the clothes I'd caught her in when she climbed back through her bedroom window at 2:00am. Two weeks grounded. Are you actually serious right now? She grabbed a pillow and screamed into it. I was just at Tyler's party. Everyone was there. Everyone except you because you weren't allowed to go. I. I stood in her doorway, exhausted from waiting up. You snuck out. That's the issue. She sat up, mascara smeared under her eyes. Sadie's mom would never do this. She literally called the school last week and lied about Sadie being sick. When she skipped, Amelia kicked off her shoes. She trusts Sadie to make her own choices. She doesn't treat her like a prisoner. That's not trust, Amelia. That. That's being a cool mom who actually has her daughter's back. She stood up, fists clenched. All I want is a mom who covers for me sometimes instead of punishing me for being a normal teenager. Why can't you be like her? That night, I couldn't sleep. Amelia's words kept echoing in my head. Maybe I was too strict. Maybe kids did need freedom to figure things out. Her dad had been the lenient one before the divorce and she'd always loved him more. Was I pushing her away? The next morning, I knocked on her door. School today, if you want, I'll Call you in sick. Amelia's jaw dropped. Wait, what? You said you wanted me to have your back, so I'm having your back. She skipped three days that week. I called the attendance office, each time faking a cough. Amelia has the flu. Friday night she stumbled home at 1:00am, clearly drunk. The old me would have lectured her until sunrise. Instead, I helped her to bed, left water and Advil on her nightstand. I mumbled, thanks, mom, before passing out. I'd lay awake terrified, but kept repeating what I read online. Teenagers need autonomy. Natural consequences teach better than punishment. The lies got easier. Amelia would text she was at the library, but her Instagram showed her at the mall. I'd see beer cans in her backpack and pretend not to notice natural consequences. I reminded myself she'll learn on her own. Amelia started coming home with hickeys, peoples dilated, smelling like weed. Her sweet friends stopped coming around. Now it was kids with tattoos and vape pens who never came inside, just honked from the driveway at midnight. But Amelia seemed thrilled with the new me. She kissed my cheek randomly, bragged to friends on the phone about how chill I was. My mom literally doesn't care what I do, I heard her say proudly. Those words should have been my wake up call. Instead, I smiled, thinking I'd finally gotten parenting right. Thursday night, Amelia texted at ten PM, sleeping over at Sadie's to study for bio Test. Her dad called immediately, voice tight with concern. School night sleepovers. Since when I kept my voice casual. She needs freedom. Remember, I already said yes. But at eleven PM, Sadie's mom called. Is Sadie at your house? She said she was studying with Amelia. My stomach dropped, but I heard myself lying. No, haven't seen her. Maybe they went to another friends. I hung up knowing both girls were lying. But I committed to this path. At 1:00am, Amelia texted again. Actually at a party staying with a friend from school. Her dad was at my door in 10 minutes demanding we get her. She's being honest with us now. We have to trust her. God, I was an idiot. At 3 a. M, my phone rang. Amelia's voice was tiny, terrified. Mom, please come get me. Please. She was sobbing so hard she could barely speak. I'm at this college party. These guys said they were seniors, but they're like 25. One won't let me leave his room. He keeps giving me drinks. I locked myself in the bathroom when he tried to. Her voice broke. Mom, I'm scared. I flew out the door speeding.
NA

Why did my dad's no closing doors rule get him arrested? We had the weirdest rule in probably the entire state. No closed doors while changing clothes, ever. Not my bedroom door, not the bathroom, not even the closet. Teenagers hide tattoos all over their body if we let them, dad would say. Or they could be hiding pills in their pockets. My friends were horrified when they heard about it. Mickey came over once and watched me change from school clothes to normal ones right in the middle of our living room while dad sat there with his newspaper, glancing up every few seconds. That's so creepy, she whispered, and I wanted to disappear. My older brother had already escaped to college, partly because of rules like this. I counted days until I could leave, too. Mom tried to help without directly challenging dad. She couldn't change his mind about the rule, but she found ways around it. The shower has frosted glass, I mentioned one day while folding towels. You're only visible as a shadow. She also helped me rearrange my room, putting my full length mirror at an angle where it looked like you could see everything from the doorway, but there was actually a blind spot. Perfect for 30 second wardrobe changes. I got really good at it, too. I kept spare clothes in the bathroom and changed when dad was busy watching TV. Mom would create distractions, calling dad to fix something right when I Needed to change for school. For weeks, this worked perfectly. Dad thought he was enforcing his rules since doors stayed open. He even bragged to his co workers about how his visibility system kept me safe. But then one weekend, everything exploded. And ways I never imagined. Dad's colleague Rob came by to drop off work files. Dad was on a video call in his office. Mom was grocery shopping, and I just gotten home from track with my entire body sweating. I couldn't wait for Dad's call to end, so I ducked behind my mirror. Blind spot, like always. But Rob didn't know our house layout. He was looking for Dad's office and saw what looked completely wrong from his angle. A teenage girl hiding behind furniture to undress. He looked away immediately, but asked me a question that sounded oddly serious. Where's your father? I pointed to Dad's office, and he took off through the door. I heard him say, Jim, your daughter was hiding behind furniture to change clothes. Combined with these visibility rules you mentioned. Dad came out confused at first. She knows the rules about doors. Rob shook his head. Jim, she was hiding behind furniture to change. That is not okay. You're making her feel unsafe. The way he said it made Dad's face go pale from realization. By the next morning, everything was chaos. Rob, being a mandated reporter, had called CPS overnight. Two social workers showed up before breakfast asking to speak With me. Privately, they separated us into different rooms. Dad in the kitchen, me in the living room, mom in the bedroom. Can you explain the rules about changing clothes in your house? The woman asked gently. I'm just not allowed to close doors, I said. Not even while changing clothes? She wrote something down. So you felt the need to hide behind furniture because your dad doesn't give you privacy? I tried explaining the mirror trick, but it sounded worse out loud. So you developed evasion strategies to change clothes. She kept on writing in her notepad. Then they brought dad in. Sir, can you explain why your daughter cannot have privacy while changing? Dad's voice shook. It's just not closing doors for her safety. Kids hide all kinds of stuff. It's her body, the woman finished. And you think watching her prevents her from what? Being a delinquent? Dad nodded frantically. You require visual confirmation of your 16 year old

My mom texted me at midnight, write that you want to end your life when you're at Dad's house. I stared at my phone screen, reading it three times. Mom and dad had been separated for six months. The custody battle was getting ugly. I was 14, splitting time between their apartments and everything felt broken. Then my phone buzzed again. Call me now. Mom's voice was desperate when I answered. Did you see my text? Yeah. What the hell are you asking me to do? Your father is winning. His lawyer destroyed me in court today. I need evidence that you're not safe with him. My chest tightened. Mom, you want me to fake suicide notes? Not a suicide note, a journal entry. The therapist appointment is tomorrow. Doctor Rossi needs to see that you have these thoughts at his place. Her voice got urgent. Write that you stare at his sleeping pills count and you think about taking them when he's asleep. Mom, stop. Listen to me. If I don't get full custody, your father loses his health insurance. Through my job, you know he needs insulin. It's $800 a month without coverage. She paused. He's already rationing. You've seen it. You can't use his diabetes against me. I'm using it for him. If you write this, I get custody and I'll keep him on my insurance for the whole year. Even after the divorce, I sat on my bed feeling sick. Dad had been rationing his insulin. I've seen him skip doses, checking his blood sugar obsessively, trying to stretch his supplies. Last week, his hands were shaking so bad he couldn't open a water bottle. I can't write that I want to die. You're not actually suicidal. It's just words on paper. Write that. Being at his apartment makes you feel hopeless, that you think about ending it, that you wonder if anyone would care. She was crying, now, please for his help. The next morning, she showed up at Dad's apartment while he was at work. She handed me a notebook and a folded paper. Copy this in your handwriting. I opened her notes. The words made me nauseous. I think about ending it. I wonder if anyone would care. When I'm at his apartment, I imagine taking all 47 of his pills, he wouldn't find me until morning. Mom, this is insane. This is necessary. Your therapist already knows you keep a journal. I told her last week you've been writing concerning things. My stomach dropped. You already told her. Just copy it. Please think about your father going into diabetic coma, dying. You want that on your conscience. She left the papers on my desk. The appointment is at 3. I'll pick you up at 2:30. I sat there for an hour, pen in hand. Mom wasn't wrong about Dad's health. Last month, he collapsed at work. The paramedics said his blood sugar was at 340. The hospital Bill was $3,000 just for That one visit without insurance, he'd die. Maybe a lie about wanting to die could keep him alive. I picked up the pen, started copying the first line. Then I stopped and put the pen down, picked up my phone and took pictures of every page she'd written, every horrible word she wanted me to claim as mine. At 2:30, mom arrived. Did you do it? I handed her the blank notebook. What is this? That's my journal. It's empty. Yeah, it is. Her face went red. The appointment is in 30 minutes. Need to do this now. I'm not writing suicide notes about dad. She grabbed my shoulders. Please, I'm begging you. Just tell Doctor Rossi you have these thoughts at his place. You don't need to write anything. Just say it. Say you've thought about the pills. I'm not lying about wanting to die. You're killing your father by not doing this. No, mom, you're killing me by asking. Doctor Rossi's office was too warm. Mom sat next to me, her leg bouncing against mine. So Doctor Rossi said, your mother tells me you've been journaling about some.

My cousin viciously hospitalized his brother's wife, and now he's the family hero. I found out the day of their anniversary. I drove up expecting a Celebration and instead found blood staining the front door and the window smashed. Inside, I saw Rebecca sitting on the couch getting her face stitched up, while my cousin Terry, who everyone teased for being a standoffish pacifist, stood with bleeding knuckles and a stone cold face. Terry, what have you done? Grandma was screaming while clutching her chest. Living room looked like a bare knuckle boxing ring. Blood splattered across anniversary decorations, shattered glass everywhere. You're going to prison. Uncle Pete was dialing 9 1 1. Look at her face. Twenty relatives descended on Terry like vultures. Your brother's wife, Cousin John, grabbed Terry's shirt on their anniversary. Rebecca sobbed, blood running down her dress. He grabbed me by the hair, slammed my face into the table. I thought he was going to call me, but something was wrong. Dave sat frozen in the corner, his own wife brutalized, and he just stared at the floor, not moving, not speaking, not even looking at her. Dave, why aren't you. Aunt Linda started. He knows why. Terry said quietly, the room exploded. There's no excuse. You're an animal. How could you hit a woman? But Dave still didn't move. After 10 minutes of everyone screaming at Terry, threatening him, calling police, someone finally asked Terry why. Terry finally answered, she's been beating Dave for Three years! Liar! Rebecca lurched forward, but Uncle Pete held her back. Remember Christmas when Dave had that broken rib? She hit him with a baseball bat while he slept. The work scars on his back. She threw boiling water on him. If she hit him, why did he never fight back? Cousin John asked sarcastically. Terry pulled out his phone and Rebecca's voice filled the room. Try to leave and I'll tell everyone you molested Liam. I'll bruise myself up, tear my clothes and Christ the goose assault to the police. Who will they believe, Dave, the sobbing woman or the man? People's faces turned, but the recording continued. You eat when I say, you sleep where I say. Dave's voice cut through. Please just let me spend time with my boy. Then Rebecca shooting back, you see Liam only when I allow it. Or I make one phone call and you never see him again. I have friends who'll testify they saw you hit me. The tension in the room grew. Uncle Pete slowly let go of Rebecca's arm, stepping back. Grandma turned to Rebecca. You threatened. And him? Rebecca tried to speak, but Aunt Linda cut her off. All those times Dave had bruises, that was you. Why didn't anyone tell us? Mom asked, looking around. I did tell you! Terry's voice exploded. I told you about the bruises. You said couples fight. I told grandma about the cigarette burns. She said Dave needs to man up. I begged Uncle Pete when I saw the burn marks. He said, not our business. Mom's hand covered her mouth. Oh god, you did tell me. Grandma looked at the floor. I thought men should handle their own problems. Went to the police three times, Terry continued. They said Dave had to file the complaint himself. So he tried. Then she showed up at the station with self inflicted bruises on her arms. They nearly arrested him. After that, he never tried again. Aunt Linda stepped away from Rebecca. Jesus Christ, Rebecca, how could you? Dave was almost in tears when he stood up and slowly lifted his shirt. Cigarette burns covered his ribs and long scars on his stomach. The room gasped. Uncle Pete pointed at Rebecca. You did this! You burned him! This is what she did. Because I tried to report it. Rebecca's mask was cracking. You pathetic little. But there's something else even more disgusting. Everyone froze completely. What do you mean? I whispered. Liam came to me a few days ago. Terry's voice broke. He asked me why mommy makes him do photo

When did you realize your teacher was using you for free labor? The principal stops reading my college rejection letter, my third one this week, and looks up at me. Your GPA is excellent, she reads, frowning at her screen. But it says here you have zero extracurriculars. I explained to her that I stay after school every day to help other students, but the principal frowns, saying, the activities log shows you've never joined a single club or done even an hour of community service. I tell her I'm literally in room 2:03 until 6:30 p m. Every day, sometimes until 9 during playoffs. Just ask Mister Hayes. She pulls up security footage on her computer, and there I am in room 2 0 3 with five varsity football players, including our state champion quarterback, writing five different essays while they're on their phones. The principal's face goes white as she asks me, you're doing their homework? I'm confused. I explained to her that Mister Hayes says it's pure tutoring for my college application, but she types something into her laptop and turns the screen toward me, saying, there's no record of any tutoring program in our system. My mouth goes dry, and I feel my stomach dropped through the floor because I've been doing this for three years, every single day after school, all while Mister Hayes told me Harvard loves students who help athletes succeed. However, I can only assume Harvard doesn't love students who do athletes Homework for them. The principal calls in the guidance counselor, who pulls my record, saying, you've missed every college prep meeting. I explained that Mister Hayes said the tutoring was more important. The counselors fingers freeze over the keyboard. The counselor asks, did you write your own college essays yet? And I tell them that I started them. Mister Hays said they needed editing. She asked me if he edited them, and I admit no. He said I should focus on helping the team first. The counselor's face goes pale and she grips the edge of the desk as she says, you missed your own deadline, helping others meet theirs. But I defend him, my voice getting smaller, saying Mister Hays says the team brings in thousands of dollars to the school, and my grades are good enough as is. I should help those who have a lower chance of success. The principal shakes her head and something in her eyes makes my chest tight as she says, your grades are excellent, but colleges rejected you because you're a ghost with no activities, no personality, no recommendations that aren't about how helpful you are to others, just grades. That's when it hits me like a punch to the stomach. I realized I spent so much time writing everyone else's story, I forgot to write my own. Mister Hayes freezes in the doorway when he sees us, his coffee cup halfway to his lips, and he tries to turn around and Leave. But the principal calls him in, asking about his tutoring program. Mr. Hays sets down his coffee and acts casual, saying, oh, she's our best tutor. So helpful to everyone. Then the principal turns her laptop toward him, showing the security footage, and his face change, just completely, going from fake smile to cornered animal. He says, those students need support. They have learning differences. His voice is getting higher, saying, do you know how much the sports program brings in? Then he turns to me, desperate now, saying, tell them how much you love helping. Tell them. But I stay silent. And for the first time in three years, I don't defend him. The counselor is in Mister Hayes's face. You told a student this would help their college applications? The principal's pen snaps in her hand as she tells him, doing homework for others isn't community service, it's academic fraud. Then Mister

What's the most heartbreaking thing you've heard about your dad? I was 22 when I applied for my dream job. Standard background check, they said, no big deal. Then HR called me a week later, said there were red flags with my application. Said there was a gap in my dad's employment history that concerned them. The same dad who always bragged about his perfect career trajectory? The same dad who said we moved when I was 12 for his big ocean. I told HR it must be some confusion. My dad was a successful construction worker. But they suggested I look into it before proceeding. I googled my dad's name with our Old Town. First result was a newspaper archive from 2,014. It said our local youth coach was under investigation for misconduct. My dad's face staring back at me. Click link after link. Parents demanded answers at emergency school meetings. One said second student comes forward. Third allegation rock soccer program. Every article dated the exact week we left. Dad had said the promotion opportunity came up suddenly, so we had to leave immediately or he'd lose it. Mom cried for three states straight. I thought she was sad about leaving her friends. The articles painted a clear timeline. March 3rd, first complaint filed. March 8th, school suspended him from coaching. March 15th, police opened investigation. March 18th, we moved. No forwarding address, no goodbye parties, no nothing. Just gone. The last article was from March 20th. Suspect in youth abuse case disappears. They Use the word suspect. My dad was a suspect. The reporter included a quote from a parent. He knew we were onto him. Back up and ran like a coward he is. Those boys deserve justice. I called the newspaper, asked for the reporter who covered the story. She still work there? Remembered everything. Said my dad was the assistant coach for three different teams. Multiple boys came forward independently. They had similar stories about private training sessions. The detective was building a case when we vanished. One family hired a private investigator, but trail went cold in Nevada. We lived in Nevada for six months before moving to Arizona. Dad said it was for tax purposes. Public records request got me the police files. Three boys gave statements, ages 11, 12, and 13. Detailed accounts of what happened in the equipment room after practice. What happened in my dad's car during rides home. What happened during tournament, hotel stays. One boy's statement mentioned me. I was always around, but never knew. My dad would buy us both ice cream afterward. He had to watch me laugh and eat my cone while he felt sick. That boy was Preston, my best friend. He suddenly stopped coming over that last month. Mom said his family was dealing with personal issues. I confronted my dad with everything. Printed out 40 pages of articles, police reports, witness statements. He went pale, started stammering about misunderstandings. And I showed him Preston statement. The one That mentioned me. The one that described specific dates, times, places he broke. Admitted everything. Said he had a problem and got help. He said that's why he never coached again, never volunteered, never came to my school events. He was keeping himself away from kids. Mom sat there.

My wife said we should split everything since we both make good money. But she wasn't laughing when I took her literally. I've been married to Lisa for five years. I'm an engineer making 78 k. She's a nurse practitioner making 82 k. Always pulled our money together into joint accounts. Last month, Lisa comes home from her girls night all excited. Babe Sarah and Jen both have separate finances with their husbands. We're both doing so well financially. What if we each just handle our own expenses? More independence, you know, more modern. Honestly, it sounded reasonable. We're both adults making decent money. Why not? Sure, let's split everything, 50, 50, rent, utilities, groceries, insurance, everything. She seemed a bit surprised by how specific I was getting. Well, I meant more like we each pay for our own stuff. You handle the bills you want, I handle mine. More flexible. Red flag, but I agreed anyway. Maybe she had a point about flexibility. So the next day I sat down with our budget and divided everything perfectly down the middle. Rent one, $400 each. You utilities, $150 each. Internet, $50 each. Groceries, $400 each. Insurance, $200 each. Car payments, gas, personal expenses, all separate. I made a nice little spreadsheet and showed her. She said, wow, okay, very thorough, but seemed a little overwhelmed. Here's what I didn't expect. Lisa is absolutely terrible with money, always has been. I just never noticed because I've been handling all our finances. For five years, never had to budget or track expenses. Week 2, hey babe, can you cover utilities this month? I bought this amazing Korean skincare set that was on sale. I'll pay you back next week. Week 3, my half of rent is gonna be a few days late. Had to get my car detailed and got those highlights I've been wanting. You don't mind covering me, right? Week 4, can you grab groceries this week? I'm a little short until payday. Work has been so stressful. I deserve that shopping trip. I started keeping track of every loan in my phone just out of curiosity. Meanwhile, I'm actually thriving without her impulse purchases draining our joint account. I'm investing my leftover money, started putting $800 a month into index funds, something I never could do before because money would just disappear. Peer month two, she owes me one I ton and $50 in temporary loans, rent, utilities, groceries, even her portion of our anniversary dinner at that expensive steakhouse she insisted on trying. It's just temporary, babe. Once I get my spending under control and figure out this whole budgeting thing. But it's actually getting worse instead of better. She's buying a hundred and fifty dollar Lululemon sets, three different subscription boxes, constantly eating out for lunch instead of packing like she used to. Getting her nails done every two weeks at $80 a pop. She makes $4,000 more per year than me, but somehow always comes up Completely short. Month three, she's sitting at our kitchen table at eleven PM crying actual tears because her credit card is maxed out at 4,000 dollars. She can't make her 320 dollar car payment that's due tomorrow. And according to my phone notes, she owes me exactly 3,400 dollar total. I don't understand how this happened. I make good money. I should have way more left over than you do. I pulled out my phone and open my investment app, turn the screen toward her. 20 eight hundred dollars built up in just three months even while covering most of her expenses and maintaining my own lifestyle. This is absolutely crazy, she said, staring at the screen like it was displaying alien hieroglyphics. You're like actually wealthy now. How are you?

What's the meanest thing your friends did because of money? My jaw dropped at my friend's audacity. Chuck is literally such a freaking loser. I don't know why we kept inviting him to things, Serena said, rolling her eyes when I asked where he was. But he's been our friend since college, I said. Nate groaned. That's exactly the problem. We all went to the same college, and now he's stuck working at target. It's embarrassing. Dan nodded. Last time he was here, he ordered water and the cheapest thing on the menu. But you guys order water, too? Sometimes, I argued. Serena slid her Ray Bans down and stared at me with a bored expression. We're 27 now. It's time to upgrade to better friends. As if that Sunday brunch wasn't horrifying enough, that same night when Chuck texted the group chat saying, hey guys, really need someone to talk to, Serena made a separate group chat just to mock him. Ten bucks says he needs money, not a talk. Just don't respond. We're not his ATM. They laughed at him in the chat. I made sure to call him secretly. Hey, Chuck, what's up? Chuck sniffled. Just a terrible time right now. I. My mom's test results came back from the hospital. Stage three. My eyes widened. Okay, stay where you are. I'm headed over to your house. I spent that night at Chuck's place. We drank cheap beer and watched old comedy specials while his mom slept. Upstairs, Chuck didn't cry again, just kept saying it is what it is every time his voice started to waver. In the morning, I texted the group chat. The one without Chuck asking. Hey, could you guys come over to Chuck's place? His mom's seriously sick and he could use some friends. But Serena, Nate, and Dan all made different excuses not to go there for him. I'm busy on this presentation. I have a networking event today. Sorry, can't need sleep. Chuck smiled, saying that it's fine. But it wasn't. Over the next few weeks, as Chuck's mom got worse, so did my friends. When Chuck posted a gofundme for medical bills, Serena screenshot it in our separate chat. Called it I knew he wanted money. She reported it as a scam. Nate saw Chuck at the grocery store and literally hid behind the cereal aisle. I can't deal with his sob story right now. He texted us with a selfie of him crouching behind cans of spam. Dan went further. He unfriended Chuck on everything. I don't need that negativity in my feed, he said at brunch while showing us his vacation photos. Besides, it's manipulative how he keeps posting about his mom. We get it, she's sick. Does he really need to bring down the mood with that? Like, let me doom scroll through Hot Girls in Peace. Nate burst out into laughter at his comment. Serena smirked, unfriending him too. I felt sick. How could things Have gotten so different since college. Chuck's mom passed that same week. I attended his funeral. Sat in the front row with his co workers. Almost 100 people came out to support, all boasting about Chuck and his mom's kindness, while our Three Stooges, Nate, Serena, Dan were nowhere. I thought they'd at least text, Chuck said quietly. But Karma soon caught up with them and hit each person with a vengeance. Nate went first. Panic attack during a million dollar presentation. Full breakdown. Crying, hyperventilating. Had to be carried out on a stretcher in front of the entire board. When he texted the group chat asking for someone to help him with his panic attack, no one responded. Serena was next. After working 22 hours straight, she sent her clients confidential files to their competitor, five

What's the most adult decision you had to make before you turned 18? When I was 17, my older brother Matthew was diagnosed with kidney disease. This wasn't completely unexpected. He'd been feeling unwell for months. We all thought it was just stress from college. The diagnosis changed everything. The doctors explained he would need a transplant within a year. Our parents immediately got tested, but neither was compatible. My sister Barbara, who is 22 and living across the country, flew home to get tested, too. She wasn't a match, either. That left me and our cousins, aunts and uncles. Everyone agreed to get tested. I didn't think much about what it would mean if I was a match. I just went to the hospital with my mom, gave blood samples, and went through a physical exam. Two weeks later, the transplant coordinator called our house. I picked up because everyone else was out. You're a potential match for Matthew, she said. We need you to come in for additional testing. I hung up and sat at the kitchen table for an hour, not moving. When my mom came home with groceries, I told her. She put the bags down and started making calls to my dad and Barbara. The additional testing was more intense. They explained all the risks. Complications from surgery, potential long term effects, recovery time. I would miss at least three weeks of school during my senior year. There was also a small chance my remaining Kidney could fail someday, which would put me in Matthew's position. I didn't tell any of my friends what was happening. Sylvia, my best friend since elementary school, knew something was wrong, but stopped asking when I changed the subject repeatedly. I didn't want advice or sympathy. This wasn't a decision I could crowd source. My parents were careful not to pressure me. It has to be your choice, my dad said during dinner one night. That made it harder somehow. Part of me wanted them to just tell me what to do. The hardest part was talking to Matthew. He wouldn't discuss it. When I brought it up, he changed the subject or left the room. One night, I cornered him in the kitchen when everyone else was asleep. If you don't want my kidney, just say so. He looked at me for a long time. I don't want you to regret this when you're older. That was the first time I considered that this decision would affect my entire life, not just the next few months. I was planning to go to college next year. How would surgery affect that? What about playing soccer, which I loved? What about future health insurance costs? What if I had kids someday who needed a kidney? My cousin Jonathan came over one evening to play video games with Matthew. Afterward, he pulled me aside. My dad donated a kidney to his brother 15 years ago. He's never regretted it, but he Says it wasn't simple. Jonathan's dad was my uncle Dexter, who I rarely saw because he lived on the West Coast. I hadn't known about his donation. The transplant team wanted an answer soon. Matthew's kidney function was declining faster than they'd initially projected. I made a spreadsheet listing pros and cons, which felt ridiculous for a decision this big. The pro column had one entry. Matthew lives. Conclusion had a dozen entries about my future. One Saturday, I ran into my math teacher, Missus Carla Peters, at the grocery store. She asked why I seemed distracted in class. Without planning to, I told her everything. She listened without interrupting. When I was 16, my parents asked if I would quit school to help support the family, she said I said no. And I've always wondered what would have happened if I'd said yes. That wasn't exactly helpful either. But it made me realize something. There was no perfect answer. Whatever I decided, I'd always wonder about the other path. The day I turned seventeen and a/2, I called the transplant coordinator and told her I would do it. The surgery was scheduled for the following month. When I told my parents, they hugged me so hard I couldn't breathe. Which made me realize they hadn't been as neutral as they pretended. Matthew found me in my room that night. He sat on my bed and handed me an envelope. Inside was a letter he'd written detailing all the things he planned. To do with his life, if the transplant worked. It was the most he'd communicated with me in months. If you change your mind, that's okay, he said. But I didn't change my mind two days before the surgery.
NA

My girlfriend said you're too boring and needed space to find herself. My girlfriend Diana broke up with me after three years, saying I was emotionally unavailable and she needed someone more passionate, more present. You're always distracted, Jake. I feel like I'm dating a ghost. When we talk, you're somewhere else. When we make plans, you cancel last minute with some lame excuse. I can't keep doing this anymore. I deserve better than whatever this is. She was absolutely right. I had been distant, barely listening during conversations, constantly checking my phone during dinner dates, canceling our weekend plans with weak excuses about being tired or having urgent work stuff that couldn't wait. What she didn't know was the real reason behind everything. For the past eight months, I've been secretly caring for my mom, who was going through aggressive chemotherapy treatments for state stage 3 breast cancer. Every single day after work, I drive two hours across town to her house, help her with doctor appointments, manage her complex medication schedule, clean her house, grocery shop, and make sure she was eating enough to keep strength up during treatment. Mom made me swear on everything I held dear not to tell anyone about her diagnosis. She was absolutely terrified of people treating her differently, looking at her with those pitying eyes. Or worse, her boss finding out and pushing her toward early retirement before she was financially ready. I don't want to be the cancer lady, Jake. She Say, while I helped her with her weekly pill organizer. I wanna fight this battle quietly and get back to my normal life without everyone thinking I'm fragile or broken. So instead of explaining to Diana why I was constantly exhausted and emotionally drained, I became the mysterious, unavailable boyfriend who seemed to care more about unknown commitments than nurturing our relationship. Diana moved out on a Tuesday morning, taking her plants and half our furniture. By Friday night, she was already posting Instagram stories from fancy restaurants with Derek from her marketing team. Within two weeks, they were Facebook official with matching couple photos. Her social media transformed into a carefully curated highlight reel of romantic sunset dinners, spontaneous weekend getaways to wine country, and heartfelt captions about finally discovering authentic love with someone who actually shows up consistently and puts genuine effort into the relationship. Meanwhile, I was spending my evenings in sterile hospital waiting rooms, holding my mom's trembling hand during her chemotherapy infusion sessions and lying to concerned friends who kept asking why Diana and I had suddenly broken up after seeming so happy together. Two months after the breakup, Mom's latest blood work came back completely clear. The oncologist said she'd beaten the cancer entirely and could start planning for her future again. At her remission Celebration dinner at her favorite Italian restaurant, Diana's younger sister Claire happened to be there. Turns out she'd recently started working at Mom's Insurance Company, and they developed a Close friendship during Mom's treatment period, bonding over their shared love of mystery novels. Claire sees the Celebration photos on my Instagram story and immediately starts connecting dots in her head. She realizes.

My boss said, we're all family here. So I started treating him like my actual father. I've been killing myself for five years at my job when Jimmy, my boss, called me into his office on a random Tuesday. Kevin, we're demoting you, he said, not even looking up from his MacBook. My heart stopped. I've never been late, handed in my work on time. It just didn't make sense. Your position is being given to my nephew, Bartholomew. He just graduated and needs leadership experience. My coffee went cold in my hand. You're demoting me to make room for your nephew? You'll be supporting him. But, hey, that's what family does. We help each other out. We're all family here, remember? I just closed on a house based on my senior developer salary, my mortgage. Family makes sacrifices, Kevin. Bartholomew needs this opportunity. And family support each other unconditionally. Plus, I need you working weekends. The whole team does. Family doesn't watch the clock. I stared at the motivational poster behind him. Family. Together, we achieve more. Right? Family. He beamed. See? I knew you'd understand. Family values are what make this company special. Monday morning, I walked straight into Jimmy's office without knocking. Morning, dad, I announced cheerfully, plopping down in his chair while he was getting coffee. Family doesn't need appointments, right? His face went red. Kevin, this is highly unprofessional. But we're family. You said so yourself. Can I borrow your Tesla This weekend? Jimmy gripped His coffee mug so tight, his knuckles went white. At lunch, I started eating his meal from the executive fridge. Jimmy stormed into the breakroom. It's my lunch! My mom always said, family shares everything. Your salmon tastes great, by the way. I took another bite while maintaining eye contact. He yanked the container away, breathing heavily. Tuesday, I submitted an official request to HR for tuition reimbursement. Jimmy is like a father to me. Said so. And my dad paid for my sister's MBA. HR called Jimmy immediately. He showed up at my desk red faced. We don't have a tuition program. But dad, family supports each other's growth. You supported Bartholomew's growth into my job. His jaw twitched. The court quarterly board meeting made his forehead vein throb. When he introduced me to investors, I interrupted, actually, this is my dad, Jimmy. The investors looked confused. Jimmy smile became manic. Kevin's joking. Dad's been having memory issues lately. I stage whispered. Jimmy's face went purple. The entire room went silent. I started calling him dad in every email CC in the entire company. At at that point, everyone called him Dad. Jimmy sent 17 emails demanding I stop. I replied all each time. Dad's cranky today. Someone needs a nap. When Bartholomew struggled with basic coding, I loudly announced, don't worry, Bartholomew. Grandpa Jimmy didn't hire you for your skills. That's what family nepotism is for. Jimmy burst from his office conference room. Now during his 20 minute Lecture about professionalism. I just kept nodding. You're right, dad. Family should communicate better. By Thursday, I brought my laundry to work. Dad. The machine at my apartment broke. Mind if I use yours? I started folding underwear during his client call. Then I asked his secretary for Jimmy's Netflix password because family shares streaming services. By week two, others joined in. Kelly from accounting started calling him papa Jimmy and asked for college tuition reimbursement. My real dad paid for my education. Caleb from IT brought his kids to the office. Uncle Jimmy can babysit while I code, right? That's what family does. His assistant said she'd never seen him take three Advil at once before. The hospital called him the following week. Mister Jimmy, you're listed as Kevin's emergency contact and next of kin. He's fine. Just need someone to sign these forms. He drove there furious, only to find me getting a routine check up. Families take care of each other's medical decisions, dad. By week three, Jimmy was cracking
NA

At the lawyer's office, I discovered my parents left me nothing. My brother inherited everything. I quietly canceled all transfers. I'm Brett, 32, and I built my contracting business from absolute zero. Started with a beat up truck and borrowed tools, working 16 hour days until my hands bled. Now I've got 12 employees and we're booked solid through next spring. My younger brother, Bryce, different story entirely. He's 27 and has never held a job longer than eight months. Bryce is the type who shows up to family dinners and designer clothes he can't afford, talking about his next big opportunity while I'm still wearing work boots with concrete dust on them. For the past three years, I've been automatically transferring $20,800 every month to my parents account. Mom called it helping with the mortgage during tough times. Dad mentioned rising property taxes and medical bills. Never questioned it because they're my parents and 20 eight hundred dollars felt like the least I could do. But sitting in this mahogany paneled conference room listening to their state attorney read through their will, I realized how naive I'd been. Bryce inherits the house, all investment accounts and life insurance policies, the lawyer stated. Matter of factly, Brett receives the tools in the garage and your grandmother's China set, tools and China after three years of mortgage payments. It seems like an oversight, I said calmly, though my chest was tightening. My mother shifted uncomfortably. Brett, Honey, Bryce needs more support. Than you do. You've always been so independent and success. Bryce needs security, my father added. You've got your business, your house, your whole life figured out. Bryce is still finding his way. Finding his way at 27 after I'd started my business at 26 with nothing but determination. Can you explain what this mortgage is that I've been paying? I asked the lawyer directly. He flipped through documents. Your parents took out a 275 thousand dollar mortgage on their previously debt free home three years ago. Monthly payment is 20 eight hundred dollars. My stomach dropped. Their house had been paid off since I was in high school. What was the $275,000 used for? Bryce squirmed. Mom answered quickly. Bryce's Sports Bar downtown, great location, lots of potential. His fourth business venture after the failed food truck, online clothing store and cryptocurrency consulting company, each funded by our parents, each ending in spectacular failure. So you took out a mortgage on your paid off house to fund Bryce's business. Had me pay that mortgage for three years without telling me. And now you're leaving everything to Bryce, including the house I've essentially been buying for him. That's very uncharitable, my mother said defensively. I stood up slowly. You're absolutely right. I don't need your help. I never have. I walked out without another word. That evening, I sat in my home office looking at my laptop. Three clicks would cancel the automatic transfer that had been quietly draining my Business account for three years. I clicked cancel. Then I called my mortgage broker about those investment properties I've been considering. With an extra 20 eight hundred dollars per month, I could easily handle the payments. Three weeks later, mom texted Brett. The mortgage.

My sister told me I was uninvited from our family reunion, so I took my barbecue and all the drinks with me. I was marinating ribs at 6:00am when Lexi texted me, you're uninvited. We don't want you there. No explanation, just a cold dismissal from the person who never lifted a finger for these reunions. For eight years, I've been the backbone of every family gathering. I brought the smoker, bought all the alcohol, coordinated everything. Lexie just showed up and took credit while I did the actual work. She'd waltz in wearing some designer dress, pose for photos and act like she organized everything. While I was sweating over a hot grill, I stared at that text, hands covered in marinade, and typed back, fine, I'm taking my barbecue and drinks with me. An hour later, my phone exploded, 15 missed calls from cousins, uncles, everyone panicking. Wait, you're not coming? What about the food? Lexi said you bailed on us. My voicemail was completely full. Text after text rolled in. Please tell me you're joking. The reunion won't be the same without your brisket. What happened? That's when I realized Lexi's fatal mistake. She never told them she uninvited me. She just announced I canceled, left them scrambling with no backup plan. Classic Lexi, creating problems and expecting everyone else to solve them. I texted my cousin Matthew, Lexi uninvited me, but you're welcome at my place. I've got everything we need. Matthew immediately called back. Absolutely Furious. She did what? That's completely insane. I'm coming over and bringing everyone I can convince. Within minutes, half the family was choosing my backyard over Lexi's disaster. Even the neighbours wanted in. When word spread about the impromptu cookout happening on my street, my phone kept buzzing with acceptances. Uncle Hank on my way with the cornhole boards and my famous hot sauce. Cousin Liz bringing my potato salad and the good folding chairs. Even my elderly Aunt Diana said she'd rather come to mine because that girl has no business running anything important. By 10:00am, I had people showing up to help set up. My neighbour Jeff brought his outdoor speakers and string lights. The kids from down the street asked if they could use my pool. This was turning into something way bigger than any family reunion we'd ever had. Lexi started calling around noon, completely panicked. Where is everyone? Only six people showed up and I ordered food for 30. I could hear the desperation and anger in her voice. She tried to exclude me but ended up excl including herself from the real party. By one PM, I had 43 people at my house, the biggest party I've ever thrown. The ribs were falling off the bone. The beer was ice cold and everyone kept thanking me for saving their weekend kid. It was splashing in the pool. Adults were playing cards and the whole neighborhood smelled like heaven. Meanwhile, Aunt Diana called me laughing. Lexi's reunion is a complete disaster. She ordered pizza for 30 people and only has six there, including herself. She's blaming everyone but herself and having a complete meltdown in front of what's left of the family. The best part, three more family showed up uninvited because they heard through the neighborhood Grapevine about the legendary barbecue.

video_description: Lunch lady fired after giving foodto kids who couldn't pay#breakingnews #new #fyp
voice_to_text: A school cafeteria worker admits she did wrong and she understands why she was fired. For 14 years, Debbie Salzman worked as a beloved lunch lady here at Denver Place Elementary School in Wilmington. She says she would upgrade the lunch of a child who didn't have enough money or give them extra food if they said they were still hungry. If they didn't have enough money on their account, they would get a cheese sandwich instead. Friend that got a free lunch that would come back and say, Miss Debbie, I'm still hungry. Didn't you get your belly full for supper last night? And you don't know how many times I heard they didn't have supper that night. Salesman says she kept posted note IOU's and paid out of her own pocket for kids. But the district suspended and terminated her this February for, quote, not keeping track of a register and providing food to her grandchildren without payment, end quote. Salesman admits to giving her grandchildren extra food, too, but says it wasn't just them. I broke the rule. I'm the one that broke the rule.

I announced that my dad's not paying my college tuition. my dad has always been the super cheap guy who acts like he's loaded but penny pinches everything. Like we're talking about a man who buys generic cereal and then pours it into name brand boxes so the neighbors think we eat the good stuff. He drives a BMW that's literally held together with duct tape and prayers. He parks it at the front of the driveway so everyone can see it anyway. I'm a senior in high school and college application season is here. All my friends are talking about where they're applying and their parents are stressing about tuition costs. Meanwhile, my dad keeps making these weird comments about how I better figure out my future because money doesn't grow on trees. But he never actually said he wouldn't pay for college, so I just assumed he would. Big mistake. I applied to my dream school and got accepted with a partial scholarship. I was so pumped and ran downstairs to tell my parents. My mom was excited and started crying happy tears, but my dad just looked at me and said, that's nice, honey. Hope you can afford it. I was confused and asked what he meant. He shrugged and said college was my responsibility now that I was becoming an don't. I felt my stomach drop. This man had literally never told me I'd be paying for college myself. We'd never had that conversation. I Was so angry and hurt that I decided to be petty about it. If you wanted to embarrass me, I'd return the favor. The next week was my 18th birthday party at our house. All my relatives were there, plus some family friends and neighbors. My dad loves showing off in front of people, so he was in his element, talking about his successful business and giving everyone financial advice. That's when I struck. During the cake cutting, I stood up and tapped my fork against my glass like I was making a toast. Everyone got quiet and looked at me. I smiled real big and said, thanks, everyone, for coming to celebrate with me. I just wanted to share some exciting news about my future. My dad looked proud, probably thinking I was about to thank him or something. I got into my dream college with a scholarship, which is amazing, because my dad just told me he's not helping pay for my education at all.

Who is a good person who turned out to be shockingly evil? 1. Bill Cosby. He was untouchable. He was the silly uncle we all wanted. Turns out he was a monster. 2, subway's Jared. 3, Jimmy Saville. The guy raised millions upon millions of pounds for charity, some places listing it at ¬£45 million, nearly $60 million, and set up a ¬£5 million charity fund before he died. But it was all a facade to hide what he really was. To call him an evil piece of shit would be an insult to shit. 4, Jim Jones was a prominent figure in support of the civil rights movement. He contributed significantly to desegregation activism in Indiana. He also performed a lot of charity work, establishing soup kitchens and providing food and clothing to the poor. 5, King Leopold of the Belgians. He presented himself as a humanitarian who was motivated by a desire to improve the lives of Africans. He was allowed to establish personal rule over what was then the Congo Free State. In reality, his regime caused the death of millions of Congolese inhabitants, including children. They were worked to death at gunpoint, systematically mutilated, murdered or starved to death. 6. In my small rural Indiana hometown, we had this well respected dare officer who later became mayor, who later was convicted of soliciting minors and possession of CP.

What is the most insane Reddit post you've ever seen? One? Probably the one where a man sought advice on how to handle his cheating wife, was advised to file for divorce, followed through and then news broke in the real world of a mother murdering her two children to prevent her soon to be ex husband from taking custody of them. The op later confirmed the news story was indeed about his wife and children. Horrendously sad. 2, the one where a dying mother told her teen that she was the product of an affair. Reddit encouraged the girl to tell her dad the truth. She took the advice and he kicked her out. Since he was the legal father, the state made him take her back in and he reacted by making life really difficult for the girl who by this point had no one else. She posted one last time on a sub about suicide saying that she'd taken something to end her life. 3, that dude that shot his dick off, cooked it and ate it, you slash worthless. 3, 19. 4 I don't remember the sub. There was this post by a woman who said she was worried about getting raped while out at night in the city. She was asking the area she should avoid and what would have to happen for someone to get away with raping her. People figured out the post was written by a guy trying to rape someone and Get away with it.

When did you realize you married the wrong person? 1. We were in the bathroom getting showered and dressed for a friend's wedding. I was in the best shape of my life at the time, feeling good about myself, and I thought I looked good in that suit. She was finishing her makeup and I remarked at how beautiful she looked. I waited for her to say something nice in reply, but she didn't. And it just hit me. I couldn't remember a single time that she complimented me on my appearance. So I said that to her. I said, you know, I always tell you how beautiful you are and how attracted to you I am, but I never recall you ever saying that I look good or that I look handsome. She stopped applying her mascara long enough to dismissively roll her eyes at me. So I made the mistake of asking her, do you even find me attractive? And she flatly said no. I asked, why did you marry me then? And she said, I didn't think it was important at the time. I never felt so ugly and unloved. And it hurt even more when I've been feeling so good about myself for once in my life 30 seconds earlier. 2, when I realized if we weren't dating, I wouldn't have wanted to be his friend. 3, I realized that I was hiding good news from her because I knew she would make me feel bad. About it. I hope she was going to grow up and stop being selfish and childish. She never did.
