Through a test and asked if everything was okay at home. Started crying because I couldn't explain that I wasn't staying up late playing video games or partying. I was just exhausted. No matter how much I slept, my grades tanked from A's to C's and D's. I'd sit down to do homework, and within minutes, my

My new apartment came with a survival guide from the previous tenant. I just found my boyfriend's name on a murder list. I moved into apartment 42 with my boyfriend Marcus three days ago. We've been together for five years and finally saved enough to leave our parents houses. He's 24, I'm 22. And this was supposed to be our fresh start together. The apartment was way too good for our budget. Two bedrooms, city part views, balcony deposit free with a five year lease option. The landlord said no inspections, no questions asked. It felt too good to be true, but we were desperate. On our first morning, I found a handwritten note in the kitchen cupboard. Beautiful cursive writing that said new occupier of apartment 42 on the outside. Inside was a 12 rule survival guide from the previous tenant. Missus Prudence Hemmings, who lived here 35 years before her husband died in some kind of incident. Rule seemed insane at first. Never use the elevator between 1:11 and 3:00am. Ignore the window cleaner who appears on the balcony. Don't talk to neighbors claiming to live in apartment 65 to 72 because those burned down in the 80s and everyone died. Keep weapons in every room. Don't babysit Terry's kids from Apartment 26. I thought it was some sick joke until everything started happening exactly as described. At 11:00am, a friendly window cleaner knocked on our balcony door on the seventh floor. He exactly 30 minutes tapping and Calling out, never breaking eye contact through the glass. When he left, I checked every balcony in the building. He vanished completely. That afternoon, I heard the animal noises from apartment 48. Not dog barking or cat meowing. Something else. Something that sounded like it was in pain. Dying slowly, over and over again. At 8:00am the next morning, the postman, Ian, knocked. When I opened the door, he looked at me with sad eyes and said, missus Hemmings left something for you, didn't she? I'm sorry about what's coming. What do you mean? I asked. The rules aren't suggestions, he whispered. They're the only thing keeping you alive. This building feeds on people who don't follow them. That's when I noticed the damp patch on our bedroom ceiling had turned deep red overnight. Not rust or water damage. It looked like blood pooling and spreading, but never dripping. Marcus had been acting strange since we moved in. Distant, jumpy, checking the time constantly. Yesterday, he kept muttering about his early shift, saying he had to leave at 3:15.

Have you ever heard someone talking about you in a foreign language? For six months, my German neighbor Heidi had been hosting these fancy dinner parties. I could hear through our shared apartment wall. I never got invited, but I could hear everything, including when she'd switch to German with her friends. What Heidi didn't know was that my mom is German. I grew up speaking it at home, but rarely mentioned it since moving to the city. Why would I? Every weekend, like clockwork, I'd hear Heidi and her friends laughing. Die amerikanerin und die banane ist so languish. The American next door is so boring. Or the hat kind gushmack. She has no taste. Once she even joked about my pathetic dating life after seeing me bring home the same guy twice. At first, I brushed it off. Just mean girl talk, right? But week after week, it started to wear on me. I'd catch myself standing in front of my closet, overthinking my outfits. Is my style really that bad? I started ordering takeout from different restaurants to seem more cultured. And walking through our hallway with bags. God, how pathetic is that? The worst was when my mom came to visit. We were speaking German in the elevator when Heidi got in. Mom was mid sentence about her garden back home when Heidi's eyes widened with recognition at the language. She stared at the floor numbers like they were the most fascinating thing she'd ever first Seen. My stomach dropped, not because she'd heard us speaking German, but because I realized how deeply I'd let her comments affect me. I hadn't even told my own mother about the situation because I was embarrassed about not stand standing up for myself. That night, after mom left, I sat alone in my apartment, listening to Heidi's laughter. Through the wall I could hear glasses clinking, music playing, and then, right on cue, hear a mutter zephanio languidly like alswiezie. Her mother looks just as boring as she does.

What's your best instant karma story? I'm driving to work last Tuesday when this guy in a lifted truck starts tailgating me aggressively. I'm already going five over the speed limit, but apparently that's not fast enough for him. He's riding my bumper so close I can't see his headlights, flashing his high beams and honking. I don't speed up, he starts swerving into the oncoming lane, trying to pass on a two lane road with heavy traffic. Finally he finds a gap and floors it past me, but not before rolling down his window to flip me off and scream something about learning how to drive. Here's where it gets interesting. The guy immediately cuts back into my lane, nearly clipping my front bumper, then slams on his brakes to teach me a lesson about following distance. I had to break hard to avoid rear ending him. This moron is literally brake checking me after complaining I was going too slow. For the next two miles he's weaving through traffic like he's in fast and furious, cutting people off, running yellow lights, the whole nine yards. I'm just maintaining my normal speed, watching this lunatic endanger everyone on the road. Then I see the construction zone ahead, single lane flaggers controlling traffic, and a long line of cars already stopped. Mister Road Rage doesn't notice until the last second. He slams on his brakes, but he's going way too fast. His truck starts skidding on the morning dew and He slides right past the stopped cars into the construction zone. I pull up safely behind the last car in line and watch through my windshield as this guy's truck gets stuck in wet concrete that the crew was pouring for a new sidewalk. The construction workers are yelling and waving their arms as his rear wheels spin uselessly and what's probably $1,000 worth of concrete mix. But wait, it gets better.

I complained the whole time about taking

When did you realize someone was stealing from you? I've been living with Jake for eight months when I started noticing my adderall running out faster than it should. At first, I thought maybe I was taking extra doses during final stress, but the numbers weren't adding up. I'm prescribed 30 pills per month, one daily, but by day 20, I'd only have five pills left. This happened three months in a row. Jake was the obvious suspect. He had access to my room where I kept my medication, and had been acting weird. New clothes, expensive dinners, always had cash when he used to be broke. Must be miscounting, he'd say when I mentioned running out early. ADHD brains, right? The thing is, I'm a pharmacy student. Tracking medication is literally what I do. For my senior thesis, I was researching prescription drug diversion, so I've been documenting everything. I decided to set a trap. I bought a small spy camera from Amazon and hid it in my bookshelf, aimed at my desk, where I kept my medication. Then I marked each pill bottle with a tiny dot and photographed every pill from multiple angles. I also started a spreadsheet tracking the exact number of pills, their characteristics, and when I took them. If Jake was stealing, I'd have proof. Three days later, I reviewed the camera footage. There was Jake, 2 p m. On Tuesday, going through my desk while I was in class. He opened my prescription Bottle shook out several pills and put them in his pocket, but I wanted to catch him in the act and see how deep this went. I checked our university's anonymous tip form where students buy and sell things. Sure enough, there was a post from username Jake M94 selling study aids for $20 each. The post had dozens of responses from desperate students looking for Adderall during midterms. I created a fake account and message Jake's username pretending to be a freshman needing study help. Hey, I heard you have study aids available. My roommate mentioned you might have adderall. Yeah, I got the good stuff. Prescription grade, $20 per pill. Meet at the library. He was selling my medication for $20 per pill. Pills that cost me $5.
NA

She has a 115 degree fever. We exchanged glances, thinking, that's not a fever, that's cremation. If this girl's temperature was actually 115, she'd be cooking from the inside. We sped to the residence, like rushing to deliver triplets. Upon arrival, the dad was frantically pacing as if his world was ending. She's upstairs, burning up, won't respond. We charged up the staircase, prepared for severe intervention. When we opened the bedroom door, there she was. Crawled across her bed, pretending to be unconscious, whimpering. As we moved to check her vitals, I noticed a washcloth soaking in scalding water, still limiting steam. I glanced back at her. She froze, eyes wide with panic. We didn't need to take her temperature. I turned to the father. Sir, she's completely fine. He squinted. What do you mean? She fabricated the whole situation. He looked at the steaming cloth, then at his daughter, and visibly deflated. Are you serious? The girl started scrambling. I didn't intend to. I just didn't prepare for my history presentation. Dead silence followed. Then he erupted. You summon paramedics over a school presentation? She attempted justification. I thought I'd get an F. He faced us. You're free to Go. Thanks. As we departed, he slammed her door. We heard objects crashing, yelling, and him declaring, your re. You're grounded till college. Just as we reached our ambulance, he hustled her outside, shoved her into their car, and sped towards school to make her do the conviction overturn. I sued the state for wrongful imprisonment. Use the money to become a criminal defense attorney specializing in cases involving prosecutorial misconduct. Trevor got out last year. Works at a gas station now. Sometimes I drive by just to see how far he's fallen. From governor candidate to night shift attendant. The Maxwells thought they could bury the truth forever. Instead, they just delayed it until the moment it would hurt the most.

My boss, worried about bad publicity, asked me to give him a chance. The kid signed every waiver with a smirk, bragging about how he'd probably teach me some new tricks. He wouldn't stop talking about his parkour videos and how skydiving would be easy mode for someone like him. During the ground training, he kept interrupting me to explain how he'd seen it done differently on YouTube. When I tried to show him proper parachute handling, he rolled his eyes and said, I've watched literally every skydiving video on the internet. Morning of his first jump, he showed up hungover. I told him we'd have to reschedule, but he threatened to sue us for discrimination. He live streamed himself getting into the plane, telling his followers he was about to show this old instructor how it's really done at

What's the biggest power trip you've seen backfire? This cop pulled me over for reckless driving and started lecturing me about respecting authority until he realized I was rushing to diffuse a bomb threat at the courthouse. I'm driving to work when I get an emergency call. Suspicious package at the courthouse? Possible. I'm a bomb disposal technician. Every second matters. I flip on flashers and speed downtown. Five minutes later, red and blue lights. Local officer pulls me over. I roll down my window, already reaching for my badge. Officer, I'm. Save it. He cuts me off. License and registration. Do you have any idea how fast you were going? Sir, I'm responding to an emergency call. I don't want to hear excuses. You were doing 65 in a 35 zone, weaving through traffic like a maniac. This is Officer Bradley. I recognize him from department meetings. Young guy, maybe two years on the force. Always trying to prove how tough he is. Officer, I'm Detective Martinez, bomb squad. Code red at the courthouse. He barely glances at my badge. Yeah, right. Every speeder thinks they're a cop. You can call dispatch. I'm not calling anyone. You think some fake badge gets you out of a ticket? My radio crackles. All units, courthouse evacuation in progress. Bomb squad ETA requested. Bradley hears it but doesn't react. Turn that scanner off. You're not fooling anyone. That's not a scanner. That's my departmental radio. I really need to get to the Courthouse. Sure you do, buddy. And I'm the sheriff. He's taking his sweet time writing the ticket. Clearly enjoying the power trip. Officer, people could die if that device detonates. Please, just call your sergeant. Stop being so dramatic. There's no bomb threat. I would have been notified. My phone starts ringing. It's Captain Williams. Martinez, where are you? We need that device cleared now. Buildings evacuated.

What's the weirdest reason someone got offended at a coffee shop? So I accidentally started a full scale latte art controversy because I said thanks wrong. Let me explain. It was Tuesday morning. I'm running on three hours of sleep and the emotional stability of a wet napkin. I stumble into this bougie coffee shop downtown. You know the type. Edison bulbs everywhere. Baristas who look like they exclusively date people with septum piercings and a chalkboard menu written in cursive so fancy it might as well be hieroglyphics. I order a simple cappuccino. Nothing crazy. No oat milk, no extra shots, no interpretive dance on top. Just caffeine in a cup so I can pretend to be a functioning adult. The barista, let's call her Luna, because of course, that's her name, makes my drink with the intensity of someone performing surgery. She's got this little metal pitcher steaming milk like she's summoning spirits. Takes her a solid five minutes to create what I can only describe as the Mona Lisa of foam art. She slides across the counter with this proud smile and goes, I made you a swan. I look down. It's beautiful. Beautiful, like, genuinely impressive. This foam swan is sitting there looking more elegant than I've ever looked in my entire life. I'm genuinely appreciative. So I say, oh, wow, that's really cool. Thanks. And Luna's face just drops like, I told her my dog died. She blinks twice and goes, cool. I pause mid Sip? Yeah, it's. It's really well done. She crosses her arms. I spent six years perfecting latte art. This isn't cool. This is craft. Ma'am, I said it was cool because I think it's impressive. That's. That's a compliment. But Luna's not having it. She turns to her coworker, guy with a mustache that definitely has its own Instagram account, and goes, he called my swan cool. Mustache. Guy looks at me like I just vandalized the declaration of independence, bro. That's dismissive. I'm standing there holding my swan cappuccino, thinking, when did coffee shops become art galleries? With attitude, I try to backtrack. I'm sorry. I meant it's beautiful. Really skillful. Luna gasped. Skillful? It's not
NA

What's your they didn't realise I could understand their language story? I was adopted from Korea at age 3, but my white American parents made sure I kept learning Korean. Growing up in Texas, no one ever guessed I was fluent. I I was 16 when my high school got a new Korean math teacher, Missus Park. On my first day in her class, she looked surprised to see me, but said nothing. I heard her mutter in Korean, great, another banana. Yellow on the outside, white on the inside. For the next month, she'd make comments about me in Korean during class, thinking I couldn't understand. She called me the fake Korean and the whitewashed one. When I got good grades, she'd say in Korean that I must be cheating because adoptees are usually stupid. Other Korean students in class would laugh at her comments. Some even joined in, making fun of how I use chopsticks wrong or how I couldn't read Hangul. Missus park encouraged it, praising them in Korean for keeping their culture pure. During parent conferences, she switched between perfect English with my parents and Korean with other Korean parents. My parents she praised my performance, but in Korean she told other parents I was a disgrace to our people and that adoption should be banned. One day, she paired me with a Korean student for a project. In Korean, she told him to do all the work because the adopted one will just mess it Up! That's when I'd had enough. I turned to her and said in perfect Korean, I may be adopted, but at least I'm not a bitter teacher who bullies children. Classroom went silent. Missus Park's face turned white. She started stuttering in both languages, trying to explain herself. The Korean students who had laughed at her jokes sank in their seats. Realizing I had understood every insult, I switched to formal Korean. The kind you

They hid my confession to protect their son. So I made them watch him unravel live on TV. They destroyed evidence of their son's crime and left me to rot in juvenile detention. The Maxwell family. Political royalty who thought money could rewrite history. I was sixteen. House party, underage drinking. Typical teenage stupidity. When Emma Rodriguez ended up in a coma from hit and run that night, everything changed. Police found my car with front end damage. I've been drinking. Couldn't remember driving home. Physical evidence pointed to me. Vehicular assault charges followed. But I knew something was wrong. The damage was on the wrong side. Paint transfer didn't match. Three days before trial, I got a USB drive. Security footage showing the real driver, Trevor Maxwell, the mayor's son, drunk, behind the wheel of his father's identical car. Timestamp showed him hitting Emma and swapping cars while I was passed out. Perfect crime. Except for one camera. I gave the video to my public defender. She said it would change everything. Next morning, she called. Video was corrupted, couldn't be used. Suggested a plea deal. The Maxwells had bought her silence. Buried the only evidence that could save me. I took the plea. 18 months in juvenile detention while Trevor walked free. Got into Harvard, started his perfect career. But I made copies of that video. Hidden them everywhere, waiting for the right moment. Trevor became everything his family wanted. State senator at 28, being groomed for governor. I spent 10 years building my case. Financial records showing payments to my lawyer, communications between Trevor and his father, medical evidence proving my innocence. Trevor was running for governor, scheduled for a live debate, watched by Millions. Perfect Platform for truth. I had infiltrated his campaign as volunteer, worked up to social media coordinator. Had access to live stream controls. During commercial break, I uploaded evidence to every platform. The video, financial records, medical reports proving Trevor's guilt and the cover up. Before debate resumed, I texted him. Check your Twitter mention.

I told my ex boyfriend's daughter, it's not my problem. I dated this guy John for 6 months and his 16 year old daughter Tia made my life hell from day one. She called me that bitch every single time she saw me. Told people I broke up her parents marriage even though they divorced 10 years ago, and literally told me I should voluntarily leave this world. When I asked what I could do to make things better, John did absolutely nothing about it. He threatened to ground her or take her phone, but never followed through. Even her mom Chloe tried talking to her, but Tia just said she hated me for no reason. She just didn't. The final straw happened at my house during dinner. I went to pick up our food order and when I came back, John was sweeping up pieces of my grandmother's antique picture. This thing meant everything to me. It was the only thing I had left of her. He looked right at me with this smug little smirk and said, oops, it was an accident. I asked how the hell it was an accident, and she just shrugged. I think I bumped the table and it fell off. That was total bullshit. My dining table weighs like 200 pounds. You'd have to slam into it with your whole body to even make it shake. She broke it on purpose and we both knew it. I told them to leave and spent The whole night crying over the pieces. Called John the next day and broke up with him. He begged me to reconsider, but I was done. I couldn't spend my life walking on eggshells around a kid who wanted to destroy everything I cared about. Fast forward three months to last Tuesday. I'm leaving work, and there's Tia waiting by my car. She looked terrible. Eyes all red, hair a mess, like she'd been crying for hours. She started going off about John's new girlfriend, Jane. Apparently, Jane doesn't put up with Tia's crap like I did. When Tia calls her names, Jane calls her names right back. When Tia and

I threatened my wife with divorce after she quit her job to be a tradwife. So my wife Emma had been sending me these tradwife tik toks for months. You know the ones. Girls in flowy dresses baking bread and talking about serving their husbands. At first I thought it was just some random phase. He'd been married six years, and she'd never shown any interest in that lifestyle before. Emma worked part time at a dental office while I did construction. Between both our jobs, we were doing fine financially. Our kids, Aiden and Bella, were 11 and 9, so they didn't need constant supervision anymore. They were in school most of the day anyway. But Emma kept pushing. She'd show me videos of these women talking about unlimited intimacy and home cooked meals every night. I kept telling her our current setup worked perfectly. She worked mornings, I worked full days, and one of us was always home when the kids got back from school. Two weeks ago, she completely lost it during an argument about this whole thing. She literally said, fine, if you won't appreciate what you'd be getting, then you won't get anything at all. She cut me off completely. No affection, no conversations beyond logistics about the kids. He was treating me like some random roommate who happened to live in her house. I figured she'd get over it. Emma could be dramatic sometimes, but she usually came around after a few days. Boy, Was I wrong about that? Yesterday I came home from a long day pouring concrete in 90 degree heat. I was exhausted, covered in dust, just wanting to shower and maybe watch TV with the family. Instead I found a bunch of gift

What's the funniest way you've ever gotten revenge on a prank call? I kept getting these annoying prank calls from someone pretending to be conducting fake surveys about random stuff. Like, hello, sir, we're conducting a survey about how many socks you own. Or, ma'am, what's your opinion on purple vegetables? After the third call, I was getting pretty annoyed, but then I had a brilliant idea. The next time they called, I was ready. They started with their usual routine. Hello, we're conducting a survey about kitchen appliances. I immediately cut them off and said, oh, perfect timing. I'm actually conducting a survey about prank calling habit. There was a confused pause, and they said, excuse me. What? I said, since you're clearly a prank caller, this is a great opportunity to gather research data. Can you please rate your prank calling technique on a scale of 1 to ten? I tried to deny it, but I pressed on with complete seriousness. Sir, this is for scientific research purposes. I need to document various prank calling methodologies. Now, would you describe your approach as amateur or professional level? The caller was clearly thrown off and actually started answering my questions. They said, well, I guess I'm pretty good at it. Excellent. I said, now can you demonstrate your range of fake voices for my study? They actually started doing different accents like they were auditioning for a voice acting role. I took detailed notes and said, fascinating. Now tell Me. What inspired you to get into prank calling? They spent five minutes explaining how they started prank calling as a hobby in middle school. Very interesting. Now, for research purposes, can you rank your top three prank call? Top. They enthusiastically listed fake surveys, wrong numbers, and pizza delivery pranks. I said, excellent data. Now I need you to demonstrate each technique with a brief example. This person actually started performing different prank call scenarios while I pretended to take scientific notes. 20 minutes into this fake interview, I said, now I need you to rate your own performance today. They said, honestly, this might be my best work. I really felt like I connected with my subject. that's interesting, because technically, you just got reverse prank called. There was dead silence, and I could hear them processing what just happened. They said, wait, you're not actually conducting research? I said, nope, but congratulations.

What's the funniest thing you've ever done to prove a point to your parents? My parents had this annoying habit of shutting down every request I made with the same exact phrase. When you pay rent, you can make the rules. Didn't matter what I asked for your bedtime, different dinner, friends over on weekdays, the answer was always the same. When you pay rent, you can make the rules. I was 14 and getting sick of hearing it, so I decided to take them literally. I started saving. Every birthday dollar, every allowance payment, every lawn mowing job. For three months, I hoarded money like I was planning to buy a car. My parents thought I was being responsible. Little did they know, I was plotting their destruction. I looked up our monthly rent online. Turns out we paid one 2 hundred dollars a month. I counted my savings and had exactly one 2:47 perfect. One Tuesday morning, I walked into the kitchen where my parents were drinking coffee and reading the news. I slammed a stack of cash on the table and said, here's this month's rent payment. My dad nearly choked on his coffee, and my mom just stared at the money. What is this for? I said, well, you always told me when I pay rent, I can make the rules, so I'm paying rent. My dad tried to hand the money back, but I stepped away from the table. Nope. A deal's a deal. I'm Officially a rent paying tenant now. My mom said, honey, we didn't mean it literally. I said, too late. The transaction is complete and as the new co landlord, I'm implementing some house rules. I pulled out a typed list I prepared and started reading my new regulations. Rule No. 1 mandatory family dance time every night at seven PM. No exceptions. Rule No. 2 pizza only Tuesday. We're ordering pizza every Tuesday from now on. Rule number three no news during breakfast. Only cartoons are allowed on the TV. My parents looked at each other like I'd lost my mind. My dad said, this is ridiculous. You can't. I just pay rent and take over the house. I said, actually, according to your own logic, I can. You've been telling me for years that rent equals rule making power. My mom tried reasoning with me. Sweetie, we'll give you the money back. Just stop this. I shook my head. Sorry, but I've already invested in this household. As a paying tenant, I have rights. That night at seven PM, I turned on music and announced it was mandatory family.

What family rule did you break that got you disowned? My family had one rule. Never marry outside our culture. When my sister brought home James, a black song software engineer, my parents smiled politely through dinner, then told her to end it. Nice boy, wrong color, my mother said. My sister chose James. They disowned her that night. Changed the locks while she was at work. Threw her belongings on the lawn. Told the extended family she was dead to us. I was 17. Watched from my window as she picked up her clothes from the wet grass. James helping her load his car. My parents stood in the doorway like guards. Wanted to help, but my father grabbed my shoulder. You go out there, you don't come back either. For three years, I played the good son. Went to the right college, dated the right girls. Same religion, same skin color, same last names our grandparents would recognize. Sent my parents photos of every approved girlfriend, like trophies. Meanwhile, I had a secret phone. Called my sister every week. She was happy, really happy. James treated her like gold. They had a tiny apartment, but filled it with laughter. She was in nursing school. He got promoted twice. I miss you, she'd say. I miss you, too. It's okay. Graduate first, get independent. Then we'll figure it out. Senior year, my parents introduced me to perfect on paper. Right family, right background. Father owned hotels. The wedding was Planned before we'd had three dates. Two weeks before the wedding, my sister called. I'm pregnant. My heart broke. My parents first grandchild. And they'd never know. Unless. At our rehearsal dinner with 200 relatives watching. I stood up for the toast, pulled out my phone. Before I marry Praia, everyone should see who's missing. I projected the photo on the wall. My sister and James at their wedding. Her in scrubs. At graduation, them holding ultrasound pictures. The room went silent. My

What happened when you dated someone out of your league? Everyone knew Alexis Parker was untouchable. Investment banker at 28, drove a Tesla, lived in a penthouse. I fixed her AC unit when her buildings regular guy was sick. She watched me work, typing on her laptop, worth more than my monthly rent. When I finished, she said, you're different from the usual repair guys. Because I didn't hit on you? Because you noticed my MIT diploma and didn't suddenly get weird about it. Talked for an hour. She was brilliant, but lonely. Rich people, she said, only saw her money. Poor people only saw her money. Everyone saw her money. What do you see? She asked. Someone whose AC was broken. She laughed. A real laugh, not the polite one rich people do. Started texting me about random broken things. Dishwasher, cabinet door, flickering light. Half weren't even broken. I knew she knew I knew. We both pretended otherwise. One night she called crying. My engagement party is tomorrow. What parents arranged it? He's perfect on paper. Harvard Law, family money. Knows which fork to use. But? But he's never fixed anything with his hands. Never had to. Wouldn't know how. I showed up at her engage party in my only suit. Told everyone I was fixing the wine cooler. Her fiance, Christopher Hale, kept calling me the help. Alexis found me in the kitchen. You came? Your wine cooler is not actually broken. I know. She kissed me. Right there. Catering staff everywhere. This is insane, I said. My whole life is insane. You're the only real thing in it. We dated in secret for three months. She'd come to my studio apartment, amazed I could cook actual food, not just order it. I'd go to her penthouse, amazed anyone needed three bathrooms for one person. Her parents found out when her mother saw us at Home Depot. Alexis was helping me pick tile for a job. Her mother

Have you ever been banned from a drive through for being too polite? I'm at McDonald's at 2:00am. Not because I have my life together, but because I was up gooning to productivity videos and realized I hadn't eaten anything except sadness and energy drinks for 12 hours. I pull up to the drive through speaker and this voice comes through. Sound like it's been filtered through three layers of defeat and a broken dreams machine. What you want? Not welcome to McDonald's or how can I help you? Just pure, pure existential exhaustion in four words. So I respond the way my mom raised me. Good evening. Could I please get a Big Mac meal with a Coke? Thank you so much. Silence. Dead silence. Like I just spoke ancient Latin. What? A Big Mac meal, please, with a Coke. Thank you. More silence then. Why are you talking like that? I blink. Like what? All fancy and stuff. You making fun of me? No, I'm just ordering food. Nobody talks that polite at 2:00am. You being sarcastic? Ma'am, I said please and thank you. That's not sarcasm. That's basic human decency. But she's not having it. Hold on. I sit there for five minutes wondering if being raised with manners is now considered a hate crime. She comes back. My manager wants to talk to you. A new voice appears. Male, tired. Sounds like he's been managing teenagers since the Clinton administration. Sir, my employee says you're being Disrespectful? I said please and thank you. Right, but the way you said it was condescending. I'm getting accused of weaponizing politeness, like I'm some kind of manners terrorist. I was just trying to be nice. I explained. See, that's the problem. Nobody's that nice at 2:00am unless they're up to something. Up to something? I'm up to diabetes and poor life choices. That's what 2:00am McDonald's is for. Sir, I just want a burger. And I just want customers who don't mock my staff with fake politeness. Fake politeness? I've been accused of many things, but never artificial courtesy. How would you like me to order? I ask normal, like everyone else. What does normal sound like? Just say what you want. No fancy words. So I try again. Big Mac meal. Coke. Better, but lose the attitude. What attitude?

What toxic family tradition did you break that cost you everything? My Jewish family had a tradition called the debt book. Every child born into our family got their own Ledger on their first birthday. Every expense, diapers, food, clothes, school supplies, medical bills got logged with interest. On your 18th birthday, you were presented with your total debt. Mine was $247,000. Family takes care of family, my father would say. But family also pays family back. The tradition went back four generations. My great grandfather started it during the depression, supposedly to teach financial responsibility. Every adult child paid their parents back in monthly installments. Some took decades to clear their debt. My older brother Jake signed his repayment contract at 18, dropped out of college to work construction. 10 years later, still paying. My sister Maria became a nurse specifically because medical professionals pay off debt faster. When my 18th birthday approached, I did something nobody had ever done. I research. Found out child support is a parent's legal obligation. Not alone discovered that charging your children for their upbringing might actually be illegal. Learned that financial abuse is a real thing. The night of my birthday party, the whole extended family gathered. 50 relatives waiting to witness another debt book signing. My parents presented my Ledger like it was an honor. Two hundred forty seven thousand, one hundred eighty two dollars and sixty three cents. My father announced, very reasonable, Uncle Rob

What's the darkest thing your family ever did? My cousin Tommy weighed nearly 300 pounds by eighth grade. Kids at school were brutal about it, but at family gatherings, we never mentioned his size. He was just Tommy, the gentle giant who helped grandma pull weeds, always let the younger cousins win at board games, and laughed like a foghorn when something genuinely made him happy. He was everyone's favourite. Every Friday night, our entire family would gather at my aunt's house for dinner. That night, like always, Tommy was sitting cross legged on the floor playing Mario Kart with my little brother, while whiskers, our 17 year old family cat, slept in his usual warm spot near the sliding glass door. Whiskers was ancient. He had survived two house moves, four new babies, and more toddler tailpulls than any living creature should have to endure. We all joked he'd outlive us. Out of nowhere, my little brother came racing in with his new remote control car, zigzagging through the living room like a maniac, showing off to everyone. The car flew right under Tommy's legs. Just as he started getting up to grab a second plate of pizza, his foot caught on the corner of the carpet. He lost his balance. I watched it all in slow motion. His arms flailed his face, and then came the soft, dull crunch when he landed. Most people didn't even hear it, but I did. Whiskers didn't move. He didn't hiss. He Didn't cry. Just silent. The whole room froze. Tommy stayed on the floor, pale as a ghost, whispering no over and over while his eyes filled with tears. My dad crossed the room and gently picked up whiskers, wrapping him in the fleece blanket from the recliner, the one whiskers always curled up on. My mom quietly ushered the rest of us into the kitchen. From behind the doorway, I could see Tommy sitting there, shoulders heaving as he sobbed. My aunt knelt beside him, rubbing his back and trying to hold it together. But even she looked shattered. That blanket never came back. By the time we left that night, every trace of whiskers was gone. His toys, his bed, the food and water bowls by the fridge. It was like someone hit delete on his whole existence. We never talked about it again. No one.

Have you ever been accused of cheating on a test you didn't even take? So here's the situation. I have an identical twin, Marcus. We look exactly the same, sound the same, even have the same weird cow lick that makes us look like we got electrocuted by the same toaster. The only difference is he's the smart one, and I'm the one who once tried to microwave a Pop Tart. Still in the wrapper. We're both seniors, but we take completely different classes. He's in AP everything that makes your brain hurt. I'm in regular human classes for people who think algebra might be a country. Last Tuesday, I'm sitting in my criminal justice class. And yes, the irony will become clear when my teacher, Mister Rodriguez, walk. Then, looking like someone stole his lunch money and his dignity, he slams a stack of papers on his desk and says, we need to talk about academic integrity. I'm thinking, cool, a lecture about not copying homework. Time for a nap. But then he locks eyes with me. Just me. Like I personally betrayed him and his entire family lineage. You, he says, pointing directly at my soul office. Now I look around, confused. Me? What did I do? Don't play dumb, sir. I'm not playing anything. This is just my face. So I follow him to his office, and he pulls out a test paper. But here's the thing. It's not from his class. It's from AP Physics. You Know, the class I've never taken, would never take, and couldn't pass if my life depended on it? He slides it across the desk. Explain this. I stare at the paper. It's got my name on it. Well, technically, it says M. Johnson, but we have the same last name, same first initial. And the handwriting looks exactly like mine. Because it's Marcus's handwriting. Because we're twins. Because genetics is a thing. Mr. Rodriguez, I say slowly, I don't take physics. Leans back in his chair like he just caught me in the lie of the century. Really? Then how do you explain getting a perfect score on yesterday's quantum mechanics exam? I blink. I don't even know what quantum mechanics means. I thought it was a type of car repair. He's not buying it. He pulls out another paper. This one's from AP Calculus. Also signed M. Johnson. Also, my brother's identical.

Call the cops on my eight year old daughter? So I made his life a living hell. We moved into our house three years ago, and everything was perfect until Logan moved in next door six months later. He's maybe 35, works from home doing something with cryptocurrency, and has way too much time to monitor everyone else. No trespassing signs every five feet along his fence. Guy even painted his grass with some kind of spray to make it look more green, which was weird, but whatever. My daughter Zoe plays in our backyard all the time. She's 8, loves soccer, and kicks the ball around for hours. The yards are separated by one of those low, decorative fences, maybe two feet high. And sometimes her ball goes over like any normal kid. She'd hop over, grab it, and hop back. Takes literally ten seconds. Last Tuesday, Zoe was playing when her ball went over Logan's fence. She hopped over to get it, and I watched from the kitchen window as Logan came storming out of his house. He started screaming at her. I could hear him yelling about property rights and respect for boundaries at an eight year old. I ran outside and told Logan to back off. Zoe was crying and ran inside. I explained that kids sometimes chase balls. It's not a big deal, and asked him to not yell at my daughter. Logan got up in my face and said, your little brat needs to Learn boundaries. This is my property, and I don't want her stepping foot on it ever again. I told him she was just getting her ball and would be more careful, but he wasn't having it. Then yesterday came, so he was playing again when her ball went over. She looked at me through the window, and I nodded. It's a ball, for crying out loud. She hopped over, grabbed it, and started hopping back. That's when Logan appeared with his phone already dialing. I couldn't believe it. I ran outside as Zoe came back, confused and scared because this grown man was on the phone with the police about her. 20 minutes later, a police car pulled up the office

Doctor said I was lucky I didn't lose my vision. For the first few days, I felt terrible for Emma. She was absolutely destroyed. She barely ate, couldn't sleep, kept apologizing every five minutes. I could see how guilty she felt, and I genuinely didn't want her to torture herself over it. It was an accident, right? She didn't mean to almost kill me over a spider. But then I started thinking about it more. I talked to Tyler and his girlfriend, who saw the whole thing. They said it wasn't just, like, a quick reaction. She grabbed that candle holder and kept hitting me. Even after the spider was obviously gone. Even after I was bleeding and unconscious on the deck. The burns healed slowly. Every morning, I'd look in the mirror and see these angry red marks all over my face. People at work would stare, and I'd have to explain that my fiance accidentally burned my face off because of a spider. It sounded insane, even saying it out loud. Three weeks later, we were having dinner, and Emma was telling me about her day when a fly landed on the table. Just a regular house fly. She saw it and immediately grabbed a kitchen knife. Not to kill the fly. She was holding it like she was ready to stab something. The look in her eyes was the same look Tyler described from that night. That's when it hit me. This wasn't just about being afraid. Of bugs. Something was seriously wrong here. And I was the one who was going to pay for it next time. I sat her down the next day and told her I thought we should call off the engagement. I tried to be gentle about it. I said I didn't blame her, and I didn't want her to blame herself either. But I couldn't risk going through something like that again. She completely

What's the most ridiculous reason you've been called suspicious? So I'm at the park on a Wednesday because my roommate brought his Twitch E girl home, and I'd rather touch grass than hear him raising up someone who sounds like a squeaky toy. I find a bench, pull out my fantasy novel about dragons and emotional damage, and start reading like a normal human being. Everything's peaceful. Then this woman power walks over. Let's call her Karen, because the universe has a sense of humor. She's got that I peaked in high school and manage a Facebook neighborhood watch energy. She stops in front of me, hands on her hips like she caught me selling drugs. Excuse me, she says, but what exactly are you doing here? I look up from my book. Reading. She squints at me like I just spoke ancient sumerian. Reading what? I show her the cover. It's got a dragon and some dude with a sword. That's suspicious, she declares. I blink. Reading fantasy is suspicious? No, she says, pulling out her phone like she's about to call the FBI. Reading alone in public on a Wednesday? Ma'am, when did literacy become a crime? Should I've brought a reading buddy? Do I need a permit for solo book consumption? It's weird, she continues. Normal. Normal people don't just sit in parks reading books. I look around. There's literally three other people reading right now. There are, like, three other people reading right now. Point out She looks around, sees them and looks back at me. Yeah, but they look normal and I don't. You're too focused. It's unnatural. Apparently I was reading with too much concentration. Like I was decoding state secrets instead of finding out if the dragon gets therapy for his trust issues. Then she starts listing my suspicious behaviours like she's been taking notes. You've been here for 47 minutes. You haven't checked your phone once. You're sitting perfectly still. That's not normal human behaviour. It's called paying attention to what I'm reading. Exactly. Too attentive. Serial killers are attentive. She just compared me to serial killers because I wasn't scrolling TikTok every five seconds. That's when her friend shows up. Another woman who looks like she exclusively shops at target. What's happening, Linda? She asks this man, Karen point

What's the most insane coincidence that's ever happened to you? I was flying to Chicago for a job interview when my flight got delayed for six hours. I'm sitting at the gate feeling sorry for myself when this old man next to me starts having trouble breathing. Everyone's just staring, so I help him sit down and get him some water. He thanks me and we start talking to pass the time. He tells me he's flying to see his grandson graduate college. But he's nervous because they haven't spoken in 15 years. Apparently, his son died in a car accident. He blamed his daughter in law for it. He said some horrible things and she moved across the country with his grandson. He's been trying to reach out for years, but she won't return his calls. He finally decided to just show up at the graduation ceremony. I felt bad for him and told him about my own situation. How I was flying to interview for my dream job. But I was terrified because I've been unemployed for eight months and this was my last shot. We spent hours talking and he gave me advice about staying confident. When our flight finally boarded, we exchanged numbers and I wish each other luck. Three days later, I'm sitting in the waiting room for my interview and the receptionist calls my name. I walk into the office and nearly fall over. The hiring manager is the same old man from the Airport. We both just stare at each other in complete shock. He starts laughing and asks how Chicago treated me. I tell him I was too nervous to really see the city, but meeting him made the trip worthwhile. He looks at me seriously and says he has to ask me something before we start the interview. He wants to know if I still think he should go to his grandson's graduation. I tell him absolutely, and that life's too short to hold grudges. He smiles and tells me I'm hired. Then he pulls out his phone and shows me a picture from the weekend. It's him hugging a young man in a cap and gown. He went to the graduation and his grandson ran up and hugged him the moment he saw him. His daughter in law had been hoping he'd come for year.

I broke up with my fiance after she hit my face and caused serious medical damage. We'd been together for five years, and everything seemed perfect. Emma was this sweet, caring person who worked as a nurse and made these incredible Sunday morning pancakes. She had this one weird thing, though. She was absolutely terrified of bugs. Like, completely loses her mind terrified. I knew about it from pretty early on. She'd see a spider in the bathroom and start hyperventilating. One time, she saw a roach in our apartment and locked herself in the bedroom for three hours until I could get rid of it. I always thought it was kind of endearing in a weird way. Like, everyone has their thing, right? We were at my buddy Tyler's house having one of those perfect summer nights. You know the kind sitting on the back deck, roasting marshmallows over this little fire pit, drinking beers, just talking about nothing important. Emma was laughing at some stupid story Tyler's girlfriend was telling about her coworker. That's literally the last thing I remember from that night. My friends traumatized a burglar. But it was so funny we got away with it. I was house sitting for my uncle during spring break when I invited three friends over. His place was amazing. My friend Sophie, who's normally the quiet one, suddenly whispered, I have an idea. She pointed to the stairs leading to the basement. We need to lure him down there. The basement had a heavy metal door that locked from the outside. If we could get him down there, we could trap him until morning when the police could come. We positioned ourselves in the darkness. One by the basement door, two behind the couch, and me near The kitchen. Then we deliberately made noise upstairs. Like we were all sleeping up there. And left the basement door open. With a flashlight shining on my uncle's expensive watch collection. Within minutes, the back door slid open. The man crept through the kitchen, crowbar in hand. He spot out of the open basement door in the gleaming watches. Just as we hoped, he headed straight for them. The moment he was halfway down the stairs, Sophie slammed the door shut. And we all piled furniture against it. We could hear him banging and shouting from below. That's when things got weird. My friend Tyler grabbed my uncle's old Halloween decorations from the closet.

He pointed at my beanie and said it was no longer acceptable. I explained calmly, it's just to cover a scar. I'm happy to buy a different one if this color is the problem. She just shook her head. Beanies are not formal. The rule is the rule. You could wear a wig if you're that concerned. I was stunned. A wig? I couldn't afford that. And it felt so humiliating. I went home that night and read her email over and over. Formal and business appropriate. That vague wording was her mistake. The next morning, I walked in wearing a fascinator. My a little corner of the office became the most popular spot for people to walk by. Brenda got angrier every day, but I was following her rule perfectly. The breaking point came when the regional director was visiting our branch. That day, I had chosen a particularly bold peacock feather.

Pulled up their denial letter and read it back to him, explaining how they evaluate each aspect separately. So I'm also filing appeals for the 100 mg dose, and for weekly versus biweekly scheduling. When did quick thinking save your life? When I was 15. I was walking home from school when a car pulled up next to me. A woman rolled down her window and said she worked with my mom. She told me there was a family emergency, and my mom asked her to pick me up. Something felt wrong immediately. Her smile was too wide, her eyes too focused on my backpack, not my face. I'd never seen this woman before. No uniform, no ID badge, nothing that proved she knew my mom. But she knew my name. And that my mom worked at Memorial Hospital. My heart started racing, but I tried to stay calm. Oh, that's weird. My mom just texted me five minutes ago and didn't mention anything. I lied, patting my pocket where my phone was. The woman's smile tightened. Well, it just happened. Your mom's really worried. Just get in and I'll explain everything. Instead of walking closer, I took step back. Actually, I need to make a quick call first. What did you say your name was again? Her eyes darted to the empty street around us. There was nobody else walking, no cars passing by. Just me and her. There's no time for that. Your mom said to hurry. Her voice got harder as she reached across to push open the passenger door. Get in now! That's when I remembered the safety app my dad installed on my phone last month. It a panic that would immediately alert my parents and the police of my location. Okay, let me just grab something from my backpack real quick, I said, trying to keep my voice steady while slowly backing away. I turned slightly, unzipping my bag while keeping my eyes on her. I slipped my hand into my pocket, unlocked my phone by feel, and press the panic button three times. The woman was getting impatient. She started to get out of the car. I don't have all day, kid. Just then, a neighbor's door opened down the street. Missus Reynolds stepped out to get her mail. I've never been so happy to see our nosy neighbor in my life, Missus Reynolds

Sweetie, you're safe here, I said, keeping my voice soft like I do with my anxious patients. Male staff won't come near you, I promise. It's just us girls here. What's the most unforgivable thing a nurse ever did? She unplugged my life support to charge her phone while staring right at my heart monitor, knowing exactly what would happen. I had been in a car crash just three days earlier. A truck hit my side of the car when a driver ran a red light. The impact shattered my ribs, collapsed my lung, and left me with internal bleeding so bad, the doctors put me in a medically induced coma. I wasn't supposed to be conscious, but somehow I was. It's called covert awareness. When your brain is active, but your body can't respond. I could hear everything around me. The beeping of machines, doctors talking about my poor chances, and my mom crying by my bedside each night. That evening, a new nurse came in for the night shift. She seemed annoyed from the moment she walked in, sighing loudly and checking her phone every few minutes. I heard her talking to someone, complaining that her phone battery was dying and she needed it for her side hustle calls later. I couldn't move, couldn't speak, couldn't even open my eyes to show I was listening. I was trapped inside myself, completely helpless. Around midnight, when the hospital floor got quiet, I heard her footsteps coming closer to my bed. She mumbled something about needing an outlet and how it's not like he'll notice anyway. Then I heard the unmistakable sound of a plug being pulled in. Instantly, the Steady hum of the machine keeping me alive went silent and the alarm started blaring. My heart raced as panic set in. I was screaming inside my head, but my body remained perfectly still. I could feel myself slipping away as the oxygen levels in my blood dropped, but the nurse didn't rush to plug it back in. Bro, you need to ask Megan out, he said, pacing our tiny room like a maniac. If you date her friend, I'll have an automatic in with Grace. Girl code, wingman duties. Double dates. It's perfect. We exchanged numbers, and I scheduled our date for that Friday night. I plan to suffer through one awkward dinner, get some Intel about Grace for Ben.

I transformed everything, rebuilt the menu, trained the staff, sourced local ingredients. Within a year, we were booked solid with a waiting list. But when old Mister Romano died last spring, everything changed. His son Giovanni inherited the place, and he had different ideas. Cut costs, use frozen ingredients. Fire half the kitchen staff. People can't tell the difference anyway, he'd say, counting receipts. While I fought to maintain the standards that built our reputation, I refused to compromise. Our lamb, also buco, was legendary. Our house made pasta brought people from three states over. I wasn't about to ruin that for Giovanni's profit margins. So on my 32nd birthday, after our biggest week ever, he called me into the cramped office above the dining room. Birthday balloons from the staff still hung in the kitchen below. Here's my surprise for you, he said with this smug grin. You're fired, effective immediately. You're too difficult to work with. I stood there, soft stained apron still tied around my waist, watching him lean back in his father's old chair like he just Solved world hunger. I didn't argue, didn't cry. Just untied my apron, set it on his desk, and walked out past the confused prep cooks who'd worked under me for years. The drive home felt endless. Three years of my life gone. My reputation, my team, my recipes, all handed over to someone who thought ketchup was a vegetable. My husband Scott, was waiting in our kitchen with a bottle of wine and that knowing smile he gets when he's up to something. How did the birthday shift go? He asked, already pouring two glasses. Terrible. Giovanni

My wife said, don't lecture my kids. Get your own. When I tried to correct my stepdaughter, I just smiled and said, alright. I'm Brandon, 38, and married to Samantha for three years. She has twin 12 year olds from her first marriage, Charlotte and Aiden. Their dad sends birthday cards twice a year if we're lucky. Last Tuesday, I caught Charlotte stealing 20 bucks from Samantha's purse. When I confronted her, she rolled her eyes and said, you're not my real dad. You can't tell me what to do. I calmly told Samantha what happened. Instead of addressing the theft, she got defensive. Don't lecture my kids about money. If you want a parent so badly, get your own children. That's done. But I just smiled and said, alright. See, what Samantha didn't know was that I've been covering their car insurance, phone bills, and school supplies for months. While she struggled with debt, I'd also been quietly setting aside college funds for both kids, $400 a month each, into savings accounts they didn't even know existed. The next morning, I canceled everything. Car insurance gone. Phone plan terminated. The college accounts I'd opened, closed, and transferred to my personal savings. I also stopped buying groceries. No more weekly 200 dollar trips to keep pantry stocked. No more paying for their Netflix, Spotify, or Charlotte's dance classes that cost me $150 a month. Aiden soccer registration fees not my problem anymore. I even canceled the family gym membership and Stopped paying for their school lunches. Every subscribe, every monthly payment, every little expense I've been quietly handling. All of it gone. When Charlotte's phone got shut off at school and she couldn't call her friends, she came home furious. Why isn't my phone working? Ask your mom, I said, not looking up from my laptop. Aiden couldn't get picked up from soccer practice because the car insurance had lapsed and Samantha's registration was expired. She had to leave work early, costing her overtime.

That's when my girlfriend Maya strutted into my home office with her three friends, all dolled up in festival gear. Ready to go, she announced like I was her personal Uber driver. Thousands of customers can't access their bookings. I literally cannot leave. Her expression shifted to that entitled look I knew too well. Are you seriously choosing work over me? I'm choosing to keep my job over driving you to a party, her friend Brittany chimed in. Can't someone else handle it? It's Saturday. Maya pulled out her phone with a smirk. Fine. If you're going to be a workaholic loser, I'll just text Derek. He's and asking me to hang out anyway. Derek? This Crossfit bro from her gym who'd been sliding into her DMs for months. Now suddenly he was her backup plan. Instead of getting jealous, I reached into my desk drawer. And grabbed a spare keychain. I tossed it to her. Take the silver Camry parked outside. She caught them looking confused. That basic rental car? I'm not showing up in some economy sedan, then called Derek. I said, turning back to my monitors. Your choice, she huffed dramatically. Fine, we'll take your boring car. Here's what Maya didn't know. That Camry was part of our fleet. That I'd borrowed while my car was in the shop. Every rental had

My roommate said, I'm moving out next month, then immediately brought her boyfriend over every night. So I canceled the Wi-Fi, turned off the heat, and scheduled the cable guy for the day. She's moving. Last Tuesday, my roommate Kayla drops this bomb while I'm making dinner. Hey, so I'm moving in with Blake next month. But don't. Don't worry. I'll still pay rent until our lease ends in March. I thought that was actually pretty responsible of her. We've been roommates for two years, never had major drama. I figured we'd coast through the final months drama Free. Boy, was I wrong. The very next night, Blake shows up with a duffel bag. And he never left. Suddenly, my quiet apartment turned into their little love nest. Blake's using my Netflix account, rating my leftovers, leaving his sweaty gym clothes on my couch. His gaming setup appeared in the living room. His toothbrush showed up next to mine. Dude basically moved in without paying a single dollar. When I brought it up to Kayla, she just shrugged. What's the big deal? I'm still paying my half of rent. He's just staying over. Staying over for three weeks straight, apparently. That's when it hit me. She wanted to double dip, keep paying for a backup apartment while test driving domestic life with lake. If things went south, she'd have somewhere to return to. Meanwhile, I'm subsidizing her relationship experiment. So I decided to optimize our living situation for the reality. She'd created. First, I called our internet company. Hi, I need to downgrade. Absolute hell for three people streaming gaming and video calling simultaneously. Next, I adjusted the thermostat to 62 degrees and installed a little lock box over it. My apartment, my comfort level. If they wanted it warmer, they could wear sweaters or contribute to heating bills. Then I said,

How I was being controlling and jealous. The irony wasn't lost on me. The woman who checks my phone when I'm in the shower was calling me controlling. I just think it's weird you'd follow me, she said, her voice getting that whiny pitch it gets when she's caught. Follow you? Babe, I'm going with Ricky. We'll probably be at different parts of the

What's the most satisfying way you left someone speechless? I transferred to the new high school halfway through junior year when my dad got a new job. Walking into Senor Vasquez's AP Spanish class, I immediately felt the judgment. I'm pale, freckled, with bright red hair. Basically the poster child for Gringo, who probably thinks Taco Bell is authentic Mexican food. Ah, our new student, Senor Vasquez said in English, looking me up and down. I hope you have some Spanish background, because this is an advanced class. Do my best, I replied in English, taking the only empty seat in the back. From day one, Senor Vasquez has treated me like a class charity case. She'd speak slowly to me in English while rattling off rapid Spanish to everyone else. the real entertainment started when she thought I couldn't understand her side comments. Pobrecito! She'd whisper to her aid when I'd pretend to struggle with vocab. This poor boy is so lost. Red hair, no brain for languages. During group work, she'd tell the other students in Spanish, help the gringo understand. He probably thinks Biblioteca means taco place. The students were just as brutal. Mira al pelirrojo! Jessica would whisper to her friends. Look at the redhead trying to roll his R's. Sounds like a broken lawn mower. Por que es que he? Miguel would mutter, why is he even here? He should be in Spanish. One with a freshman during lunch when they thought I was out Of earshot. El Gringo probably uses Google Translate for everything. Watch him fail the midterm. See, what they didn't know was that Spanish is my first language. My mom is from Guatemala, and I spent every summer with my abuela in Antigua until I was 15. But I gritted my teeth and played along. Got b's and C's on purpose. Mispronounced words I'd known since I was three. For four months, I was their entertainment. The struggling white kid who clearly didn't belong in AP Spanish. Then came the final presentation assignment. The students will present a 20 minute cultural analysis entirely in Spanish. Senor Vasquez announced this is 40%

What was the most illegal thing that happened at your school? It started when some seniors decided to pull a prank involving our school's ancient fire alarm system. They'd noticed that during fire drills, only half the alarms actually worked. And teachers just told us to follow the crowd instead of following proper evacuation routes. So they came up with this plan. They'd trigger a fake fire alarm during lunch and then hide in the bathroom to see how long it took administration to figure out there was no actual emergency. Just stupid prank to waste everyone's time for 10 minutes. But when they pulled the alarm, something went seriously wrong. The main fire doors, the ones that are supposed to automatically open during emergencies, didn't budge. Kids were pushing against them, but they were completely locked. Backup exits were chained shut from the outside because administration didn't want students leaving campus during school hours. What was supposed to be a harmless prank turned into 800 students trapped in a building with no way out. Students started panicking. The alarms were blaring, but nobody could get through the exits. Teachers were yelling contradictory instructions. Some kids were having full panic attacks, thinking there was a real fire. It took 20 minutes for a janitor to find the manual override keys and unlock the doors. Twenty minutes of chaos, with kids genuinely scared they were going to die in a fire drill. Our principal was furious about the prank, but he Was more concerned about covering up the safety violations. He suspended the seniors and tried to spin the story as students interfering with emergency procedures. But parents started asking questions. Why were the fire doors locked? Why did it take so long to evacuate the building? The seniors who did the prank hired a lawyer because they were facing criminal charges for endangering public safety. Their lawyer discovered that our school had been failing fire safety inspections for three years. The fire

My son made his sister cry on her birthday, and I've never been prouder. When my son was 11, his school bus crashed. The impact whipped his neck so violently that it crushed his airway. The doctors told us he would recover, but warned that he might never be able to speak again. It felt like a piece of him had been taken. He never let it stop him from trying to stay present, especially with his little sister, Rosie. She was five at the time, full of energy, always talking about everything and anything. And even though Nathan couldn't respond with words, he would still listen to every story she told. He'd smile, nod, or type little messages back to her on his phone. Most of the time, that was enough for her. But one afternoon, Rosie came home from school clearly upset. Her eyes were puffy, and she didn't say a word until she ran straight into Nathan's room. She dropped her backpack and hugged him tightly, tears rolling down her cheek. Nathan rubbed her back gently, trying his best to comfort her. She held on to him for a long time and then whispered, I just wish you could tell me it'll be okay. Nathan froze for a second. I saw it from the hallway. The look on his face broke me. He couldn't say what he wanted to say, and Rosie quietly left the room a few minutes later. After that day, Nathan started spending more Time alone. He would come home from school, eat dinner, and then disappear into his room. Every time I peeked in to check on him, he was already under the blanket. I figured maybe soccer practice was wearing him out or school was getting tougher, and I didn't want to push him to talk about it. I just let him rest. Then came Rosie's seventh birthday. The house was packed with cousins, neighbors, friends from school. There were balloons everywhere and a giant pink cake with seven candles sitting on the table. When it was time to sing, Rosie leaned forward and made her wish. She closed her eyes, smiled, and blew out every single candle in one breath. Everyone clapped, and then Nathan raised his hand. The room went completely silent. At first I thought something was wrong. He usually only did that when he needed help or something hurt. But this time his face was calm. Focus. He took a deep breath. His cheeks flushed.

What's it like growing up as the less loved child? For 12 years, I wasn't allowed to laugh, eat with my family, or basically exist in my own house because everything I did triggered my older brother. I'm 16 now, and my brother Jake is 20. He moved out two months ago, and suddenly my parents are acting like we're this close, happy family, but they have no idea what they put me through for over a decade. Jake has something called misophonia. He gets severely triggered by certain sounds. He. He was diagnosed when he was seven and I was four, and apparently he has a really extreme version of it. The problem? Every single one of his triggers was connected to me. My laugh, my footsteps, the way I chewed food, the sound of me turning pages when I read. Even the way I breathe sometimes would set him off. I remember being six years old, sitting in the backseat of our car, and I laughed at something I saw outside the window. Jake immediately started having a meltdown, covering his ears, yell, hitting himself. My dad pulled over and screamed at me. For being selfish and not thinking about your brother's condition. That's when the rules started. I wasn't allowed to eat dinner with the family anymore. My parents would have dinner with Jake, and when he was finished and had left the table, then I could come out of my room and eat by myself. Cold Food alone while my parents cleaned up, or watch TV. I couldn't go on family outings if Jake was coming, which was basically all of them. Movie theaters, restaurants, amusement parks. Anywhere that my normal kid sounds might bother him was off limits for me. At home, I had to walk on my tiptoes. I couldn't watch TV in the living room if Jake was around. I Learned to laugh silently, covering my mouth with both hands so no sound came out. The worst part was that I was just a little kid. I didn't understand why everyone was always angry at me for just existing. I thought I was a bad person because everything I did naturally seemed to hurt my brother. By the time I was in elementary school,

My girlfriend gave me an ultimatum to propose at her family Christmas party. But it was actually a setup to humiliate me when I found out. I gave her the public proposal she wanted, just not the one she expected. The ultimatum came on a Tuesday night. My girlfriend of two years, Laura, turned off the television, crossed her arms, and gave me a look I'd never seen before. We need to talk, she said. This isn't moving forward. My friends are getting engaged. Married. I'm 28, Alex. I'm not getting any younger. I'd always been honest about my timeline. While I loved her, there were things that gave me pause. Her obsession with appearances, her need for social media validation. How she spoke about friends behind their backs. Laura, we've talked about this, I said. I'm just not ready right now. Maybe in another year. No, she cut me off. My family's Christmas Eve party is in two weeks. I want you to propose to me there, in front of everyone. If you can't do that, we're done. A public proposal ultimatum felt like a hostage negotiation. I tried reasoning with her, but she wouldn't budge. It was the party or it was over. Three days later, her older sister Sarah asked me to meet for coffee, her voice tense over the phone. Sarah was Laura's opposite. Quiet, pragmatic, worked as a real estate agent. When I got there, she looked like she hadn't slept. She'd overheard Laura in Her old bedroom, talking to her best friend, Megan. Laura was laughing, bragging about the ultimatum. Sarah said she's been seeing someone else for a month. Her plan is to let you propose publicly. So she can say no and humiliate you in front of everyone. It would be her grand exit. Dramatic story she could tell for years. Megan was squealing with delight, promising to film your rejection. Sarah looked directly at me. She wants to ruin you just for a story. I couldn't let that happen. Something Chris

My girlfriend answers one question every night in her sleep. I think she just confessed to mass murder. When I met my girlfriend Haley, everything in my life happened way too fast, because within just two weeks, I was practically living at her place. But it didn't matter to me. She let me eat her out whenever I wanted to, was super beautiful, and even made me feel like I was the only guy on earth who truly mattered. I felt like I was on heaven until the 23rd night into us living together, because when I was just mindlessly scrolling on TikTok while I was next to her in bed, she suddenly rolled over to me and just stared at me without an expression. Ask me a question, she whispered, but I immediately realized something was wrong because her voice sounded completely flat and robotic. I nervously laughed, thinking it was a joke, but she didn't. Instead, she just grabbed my hand and yelled, ask me! So I gave in and asked, do you like it when I stick it in? Yes, I love it, she replied. Then she just turned around like nothing happened. The next morning, she looked like she had completely forgotten what happened. So when I showed her the massive wound she left on my hand, she completely freaked out and apologized a million times. I tried to forget it because I loved her too much. But the very next night, she did it again. Asked me a question. She asked again. This time I asked her, would you ever cheat on me? She just looked at me and said, no, daddy, and turned around to sleep. Every single night after that, the exact same creepy routine happened. One question, one answer, then sleep. Until one night I got super annoyed and asked what happens if I don't ask anything? She just stared at me and said, you die. Then, just like every other day, she turned around and slept. The next day, I was still horrified with what she said, so I texted her that I had to take care of my sick mom and just went to sleep at my house. But in the middle of the night, at 3:00am, she broke into my house, shook me awake, and violently told me to ask her a question. I just couldn't go on living like this, so I refused. And the second I said that, she immediately dug her nails into my skin so deep that I started bleeding. I had no idea what to do, so I asked her, when do I die? But this time she just said after me and dropped asleep on the floor. That night, I packed everything in my car, drove to the other side of the country.

My sister went missing five years ago. She just posted something horrifying on her Instagram story. Last time I saw her, she was screaming at my mom in the driveway, told us that she was done with all of us, and then stormed off into the night. We assumed she'd be back in a couple of hours, but after 10 hours with no sign of her, we knew something was awfully wrong. At first, the cops thought it was just a dramatic teenage runaway case. When they found her phone three hours later in the middle of the woods, their tone completely changed. There were no footprints, no fingerprint, and not even a sign of where she could have gone. The cops told us that she died in a river and that it was best to just move on from her. My mom started sleeping in Aubrey's bed. My dad put locks on every door and window, and I spent every night putting missing posters around town. That was 5 years ago, and I accepted the fact that she was never coming back. But last night, while I was watching some corn, a notification popped up on my phone. Yobrey Duris just added to their story. I was super confused how that was even possible, because her account was deactivated the week she vanished. I assumed her account had just gotten hacked or something. When I clicked on her story, it showed a blurry photo of Aubrey in some disgusting Bathroom. She had the same jawline, same mole under her eye, and even the same freckles, but her skin looked kind of grayish, almost like she hadn't seen sunlight in years. And her mouth was stretched into this weird smile, like she was forcing it or something. She also put a caption on it which said, see you soon, Danny. But before I could even process what was going on, my phone started buzzing with DMs from random accounts. They were saying things like, bro, is this a joke? Why is she back? Check the next story. So I tapped back on her profile and saw that it was fully active again. Her old photos were completely restored, but all the captions were changed. All kept saying things like, he feeds through me. Danny's next. I hear him breathing. But it was the pictures that shook me the most. Each one had a shadowy figure somewhere in the background, standing behind trees, peeking from hallways, or even sitting at our dinner table in one of them. And just when I thought I saw it all, she uploaded a real called home. It was a video.

My girlfriend said, let's just be friends after two years together. So I treated her exactly like I treat my other friends. With boundaries. Tara and I had been together for two years, living together, for one. We were talking about future plans, her sister's wedding next summer, where I was supposed to be her plus one. Then on a random Thursday evening, she sat me down for the talk. I love you, but I'm not in love with you anymore. She said, I think we should transition to being friends. We get along so well, have the same friend group. We'd make amazing friends. But not amazing partners. Here's what killed me. She said all this while already having packed a bag. Her friend Marissa was picking her up in an hour. She planned this whole thing down to having somewhere to stay. You've already got an exit strategy? I said, we're adults. We're friends. We can make this work. I sat there processing two years living together, talking about kids someday. Now she wants to be buddies? Okay. I said, yeah, let's be friends. She actually smiled, relieved, like I just agreed to her perfect plan where she gets to dump me but keep all the benefits of having me in her life. The next morning, I did exactly what Tara asked. I treated her like a friend. That's when I Learned she had a very different definition of friendship than I did. First text came at 7:00am. Could you drop off my work laptop? Sure. I'll leave it at the front desk of your office Monday. Can't you bring it by Marissa's? I need it for the weekend. I've got plans. Monday works better. She didn't like that. But what was she going to say? We're just friends now. Week two, Tara started cracking. She showed up at the apartment while I was at work. Still using her key. Helped herself to groceries, did laundry, took a shower. I texted her. I'll need the key back. My friends don't have keys to my place. This is ridiculous. We live together. We used to live together. Now

I already finished a bottle of wine before I arrived, and the humiliation started immediately. So you work in IT, Scarlet said with that condescending tone. How practical.
