What's the worst announcement your school ever made? When I was in my junior year, our principal called an emergency assembly that changed everything. As we filed into the auditorium, I noticed all the teachers had red eyes like they'd been crying. The principal's voice cracked as she announced that our beloved chemistry teacher, Missus Andrews, had terminal brain cancer. She only had three months left. The auditorium erupted in sobs. Missus Andrews wasn't just any teacher. She stayed late helping students with homework, bought supplies for kids who couldn't afford them, and made everyone feel special. She refused to stop teaching, saying her students gave her strength. But each week we watched her deteriorate. Her once neat handwriting became shaky. She started forgetting things mid sentence. Sometimes she'd pause during class holding her head in pain. The administration hired a substitute, Mister Parker, to assist her, but we all knew he was really there to take over when she couldn't teach anymore. He'd stand awkwardly in the back of the room, making everyone uncomfortable. One day, Missus Andrews collapsed during third period. The ambulance came, but she insisted on finishing her lesson from the floor. While waiting, she made us promise to be good for Mister Parker. That was the last time we saw her in person. School arranged for us to video call her every Friday. At first, she was still herself, cracking jokes from her hospital bed, asking about our weekends. But soon the calls got shorter. Her hair fell out, dark circles formed under her eyes. Our class decided to do something special. We turned our final project into a massive research paper on experimental brain cancer treatments. We worked through lunch breaks and stayed late after school combing through medical journals. Even the bad kids were pulling all nighters doing research. Mr Parker caught us and instead of shutting it down, he helped. He connected us with actual cancer researchers who answered our questions. Our 20 page report grew to 100 pages. We included every promising treatment we could find. The day we finished, we Learned Missus Andrews had slipped into a coma. We sent the report to her husband anyway. He read it to her every day, highlighting different sections. The doctor said even in her coma, her vital signs would improve when he read it. Two weeks later, her husband called the school. He'd shown our report to her oncologist. One of the treatments we'd found, some obscure clinical trial in Finland, was something they hadn't considered. Her doctor made some calls. Missus Andrews got accepted into the trial. The school turned our morning announcements into daily updates on her condition. Missus Andrews completed her first treatment. Missus Andrews tumor shrank 3%. Missus Andrews opened her eyes. Four months later, we heard familiar footsteps in the hallway. Missus Andrews walked into class thin and weak but alive. The three months had turned into three years. She's still teaching today.

What's the best meal you've ever eaten? My mom once made spaghetti that was so bad, it got me grounded for a month. Growing up, my mom was obsessed with proving she was a better cook than my stepdad's ex wife. She'd spend hours watching cooking shows, buying fancy ingredients, and forcing us to try her experimental dishes. The problem? She was absolutely terrible at cooking. Like, accidentally set cereal on fire terrible. But we weren't allowed to say anything negative about her food. One time, my brother gagged on her special meatloaf and had to write Mom's cooking is a blessing 500 times. When I was 14, she decided to enter a local cooking competition. The grand prize was a feature in our town's newspaper. She spent weeks practicing her signature dish, seafood spaghetti with a secret sauce. The sauce was bright orange and smelled like someone had mixed ketchup with fish food. Night before the competition, she made us be her test audience. As soon as she put the plate in front of me, I knew something was wrong. The pasta was this weird gray color, and there were whole chunks of garlic floating in the sauce. Not minced garlic, entire cloves. My stepdad took one bite, and his face turned green. But he forced a smile and said, unique flavor profile, honey. My little sister started crying when mom tried to make her eat a shrimp that was still partially frozen. When it was my turn, I Couldn't do it. I couldn't lie anymore. I took one bite and immediately spit it out into my napkin. Mom, this is inedible. The pasta is raw in the middle, the sauce tastes like battery acid, and I think this shrimp might be alive. The kitchen went silent. My stepdad's fork clattered onto his plate. My sister stopped crying and stared at me with huge eyes. Mom's face turned the same color as her horrible sauce. Instead of yelling, she got scary calm. Oh, you think you could do better? She pushed her chair back from the table. The kitchen's all yours, Gordon Ramsay. I should have backed down. Instead, I stood up and said, actually, yes. I've been secretly taking cooking classes at the community center for the past year because I was tired of eating food that tastes like punishment. Mom's eyes started twitching. Prove it. I went to the kitchen and pulled out everything I needed. I've been practicing my own pasta sauce recipe for months, tweaking at each time. While I cooked, mom stood in the corner with her arms crossed, making these little hum noises. Thing is, I actually knew what I was doing. I'd Learned proper knife skills, temperature control, and how to balance flavors. An hour later, I plated my version of spaghetti and meatballs. Look on mom's face when everyone started eating and actually enjoying the food was priceless. My sister asked for seconds. My stepdad closed his eyes and made happy Noises while twirling his pasta even mom had to admit it was good after she tried it. But I was still grounded for a month for culinary insubordination.

My girlfriend said, you're my boyfriend, so act like one. So I did exactly that and watched her world crumble. She watched me get down on one knee five times and said no every single time. Eight years together. I've been playing husband since year two. Paying her car note, keeping her on my insurance, covering most of the rent, while she found herself through three different careers. She had this whole routine down. Tears in her eyes, hand on her heart. Then some perfectly rehearsed excuse. We're not ready, let's wait till we're more stable. The timing isn't right. Then came proposal number five. And she finally showed me who she really was. I'd gone all out this time. Convinced myself that maybe the problem was I hadn't made it special enough. I rented out her favorite restaurants, rooftop, hung string lights everywhere, and invited all our friends and family there. The whole production cost me three months salary, but I thought it'd be worth it. When she finally said yes. My girlfriend stood there in the dress I'd bought her, surrounded by everyone we knew. And she didn't even let me finish the speech. Just shook her head with this pitying smile. Like I was a dog that wouldn't stop bringing her the same stick. Back at our apartment that night, I finally broke. Asked her straight up if she loved me. Why did she keep doing this? Her whole face changed in an instant. And the mask Came completely off. It's my choice when I accept a proposal, she said, voice ice cold. You don't get to pressure me with your timeline. You're my boyfriend, so act like one. Stop trying to be my husband when I haven't even accepted your proposal. Know your place. Know my place? After eight years of building a life together, I was supposed to know my place? Those words rewired something in my brain. Eight years of playing husband while she kept me a boyfriend status because it was convenient for her. She wanted me to act like a boyfriend. Fine. I give her exactly what she asked for. But boyfriends don't pay their girlfriends bills. Boyfriends don't share bank accounts. Boyfriends don't sacrifice their futures for someone who won't even wear their ring. I started my new boyfriend only policy the next morning while she was at her yoga class. First, I sold the ring to a dealer for 12 grand, enough to cover what I'd spent on her car this year alone. Then I called Verizon and removed her from my phone plan. By the time she got home from yoga, I changed every password and moved my money from our joint account. She didn't even notice until lunch, when her phone died mid phone call. Babe, my phone's not working. She texted from her laptop, annoyed but not worried. Call Verizon. It's being weird. An hour later, they said, I'm not on the account anymore. Then the panic Started creep. What did you do? I responded, I'm being your boyfriend and not your husband, just like you said. She actually laughed at first, thinking it was some kind of joke. She came home that night, acting extra sweet, made my favorite dinner and tried to cuddle on the couch. Okay, you made your point, she said, kissing my neck. I'll think about what you said. Now fix my phone.

My fiance announced he was in love with my sister at our engagement party. Five years later, he was serving us drinks at my anniversary dinner. Right in the middle of his toast, Ryan put down his champagne and said, I can't do this. I'm in love with your sister. The room with 50 people went completely quiet. Chloe stood up from table three with her face totally white. Ryan, not like this. They left separately, while I just stood there holding my champagne. My parents were screaming, but I. I couldn't even breathe. That night, my cousin texted me. They're at his apartment. I felt sick reading it. Looking back, the signs were all there. Ryan kept skipping our wedding planning sessions. Chloe was missing family dinners. They wouldn't look at each other. At my birthday party. Some of my relatives had noticed something was off, but nobody wanted to say anything. Two weeks later, they were posting photos together. Chloe was wearing the bracelet I bought her as a bridesmaid gift. Ryan was teaching her all the recipes I taught him. Our friends immediately picked sides. They couldn't help their feelings. Like our three years together meant absolutely nothing to them. I deleted all my social media and moved back with my parents. But I didn't just sit around feeling sorry for myself. I took our wedding savings and enrolled in culinary school. Then I took hospitality management classes. At night, I worked three different jobs and Learned Everything from washing dishes to being. I was sleeping in my car between shifts. My parents kept asking me to slow down, but I couldn't stop. Working was the only thing keeping me from falling apart. While I was working 18 hour days, Ryan and Chloe were living together. They moved in after three months. They got engaged exactly one year after ruining my engagement party. The ring was definitely smaller than mine had been. Everyone noticed that. Ryan kept losing marketing jobs. Chloe's influencer career went nowhere. They got evicted twice. Mom told me, Ryan asked about you constantly. I didn't care anymore. I was actually building something real. Five years later, I was running three successful restaurants when I met Daniel at a wine vendor event. He owned a Vineyard up north. We stayed up all night talking about fermentation and flavour profiles. He made me laugh for the first time in years. Eight months later, he proposed at his Vineyard during sunset. It was small and private and perfect. We had a small wedding with just family and close friends. Chloe wasn't invited. Neither was Ryan. I never told Daniel their actual names. Just said my ex left me for someone close to me. He never asked for details, but my family kept me updated on them. Ryan couldn't keep a job. Chloe's Instagram career was dead. They were facing their third eviction. Mom mentioned, she's miserable, he's drinking. Dad added, they blame each other for everything. Meanwhile, I had my restaurant empire. I had a husband who absolutely adored me. I had success that I'd earned through all that pain. For our first anniversary, Daniel insisted we eat at my flagship restaurant. Where your empire started? I tried to suggest other places, but he'd already made reservations under his name. They promised the best table. The hostess seated us at table seven with a perfect view of the kitchen. Daniel ordered champagne to the woman who turned pain into power. Then I saw our server walking over. That walk, that nervous laugh. It was Ryan. He completely froze when he saw me. The champagne glasses were shaking on his tray. Five years had not been kind to him. He had a cheap haircut and that polyester.

I gave my future mother in law three days to pay me for a new wedding dress or else I show the family a photo of her wearing it. So I'm getting married to my fiance in 6 weeks. I saved up for months to buy this gorgeous dress, $3,000. That took me forever to save working at a coffee shop while going to school. My future mother in law kept bugging me about trying it on since the day I brought it home. She'd text me constantly asking when she could see it. She'd show up to our apartment unannounced asking to peek at it. She even offered me a hundred bucks to let her try it on just once. I kept saying no because honestly, something felt off about how obsessed she was. Like, who gets that excited about someone else's wedding dress? My fiance thought I was being dramatic. He kept saying his mom just loves weddings and she's excited for us. But I stood my ground. The dress stays in my closet until my wedding day. Last Tuesday, I came home from my shift early because we were slow. I walked into our apartment and immediately heard my fiance panicking upstairs. He was texting someone frantically and blocking me from going to our bedroom. That's when I knew something was seriously wrong. I, I pushed past him and opened the door. There she was, his mother standing in front of my mirror wearing my wedding dress. My 3,000 dollar dress that I specifically told her she couldn't even look at. She had somehow gotten it on perfectly. The zipper was done up and everything. She was posing and taking selfies in it like it was some kind of photo shoot. When she saw me, her face went completely white. I pulled out my phone and snapped a picture before either of them could stop me. He started yelling at me to delete it, but I was already backing it up to the cloud. My fiance jumped in trying to calm everyone down saying it was just harmless fun and no damage was done. But I felt sick looking at the dress knowing she had been in it, taking pictures, probably planning to show all her friends. The whole thing felt violated. I told them both she had three days to Venmo me $3,000 for a replacement dress or I'm sending that photo to every single person in their family. Group chat, she burst into tears saying I was being cruel and that she just wanted to feel connected to our wedding. My fiance said I was overreact.

I wanted my daughter's boyfriend, slash soon to be fiance, to know her dark secret before marriage. My daughter Emma is 25 and absolutely beautiful, not just physically, but she's charming in a way that makes everyone want to be around her. She's got this perfect smile and this laugh that makes guys lose their minds. Her boyfriend, Tyler, is head over heels for her. The poor guy follows her around like a lost puppy and talks about her like she hung the moon. But here's the thing, nobody knows. Emma is a diagnosed sociopath, has been since she was 18, though I knew something was off way before that. When she was 8, she locked her little sister Mia in the basement for three hours just to see what would happen. When I found Mia crying and scared in the dark, Emma was upstairs watching TV like nothing happened. When I asked her why she did it, she just shrugged and said she was curious. No tears, no sorry, nothing. School was a nightmare. Teachers called constantly about Emma lying to get other kids in trouble, stealing lunch money. And once she convinced a boy to eat glue by telling him it was candy. The counselor said she was just going through a phase, but I knew better. After years of therapy and medication, Emma Learned how to act normal. She, she studied other people like a science project, copying their emotions until she could fake them perfectly by High school, she was popular, dated constantly and had everyone fooled. The diagnosis came when she was 18, antisocial personality disorder. The doctor explained it in fancy terms, but basically Emma doesn't feel love, guilt or empathy. She can't. Her brain just doesn't work that way. We've had honest conversations about it since then. When her best friend died in a car accident last year, Emma cried at the funeral and gave this heartbreaking speech later that night. She told me she felt absolutely nothing. The whole thing was an act because that's what people expected. She's been with Tyler for almost two years now. He's a good guy, works as a teacher, volunteers at animal shelters, brings me coffee when he visits. He talks about marrying Emma constantly. Last week, he asked me for my blessing to propose. That's when I told Emma she needs to tell him the truth or I will. She laughed and said I'd never have the guts. She thinks I'm bluffing because she's my daughter and I love her. But Tyler deserves to know what he's signing up for. Emma flat out told me she doesn't love him, never has and never will. She likes the stability he provides and thinks he'll be a good father if they have kids. To her, marriage is just a business transaction. When I brought it up again yesterday, Emma got that cold look.

Have you ever been mistaken for someone's plug at a quinceanera? I should have known something was off when three teenagers approached me within five minutes of arriving at my cousin Rose's quinceanera. You Rafael's friend? A kid in a rented tux whispered, sliding up next to me by the fountain. No, I'm Claudia's cousin, I replied, adjusting my tie. He looked used, then nodded slowly. Yeah, yeah, Claudia's cousin. Got it. He slipped me a folded 20 and whispered, meet me by the bathroom in 10. Before I could respond, he vanished into the crowd. I stood there holding this random 20, completely baffled. My girlfriend Patricia found me looking lost. What wrong? Some kid just gave me money and wants to meet me in the bathroom, she laughed. Maybe he thinks you're the attendant. During dinner, another teenager sat down next to me. Claudia's cousin, right? Yeah. He slid $40 under my plate. My boy said, you're good. Can you hook me up after the father daughter dance? Hook you up with what? His eyes went wide. Oh, you need me to say it? Never mind. I'll find you later. By the time they were cutting the cake, I've been approached by six different kids, accumulated $180, and was starting to piece together what was happening. They thought I was someone's dealer. The revelation came when my cousin Claudia grabbed my arm during the Electric Slide. Why is everyone asking me about my cousin Hector? Who knows Rafael I'm your cousin, Hector. Yeah, but you don't know any Rafael. She studied my face, then started laughing hysterically. Oh, my god, you're wearing the same outfit. What? There's another Hector here? Claudia Morales's cousin? Not Claudia Delgado. Me. He apparently provides party favors for high school kids. I felt my stomach drop. I have $180 in my pocket from random teenagers. You took their money? They kept shoving it at me. We spotted him during the mariachi performance, and the resemblance was uncanny. Same build, same rented black suit, same age. The only difference was his gold tooth. But in the dim lighting, who could tell? Claudia dragged me over. Hector, meet Hector. Other Hector. Looked me up and down, then burst out laughing. You're the one causing all the confusion. Kids keep asking me why I'm sitting at table 12 instead of working. Your customers keep giving me money, I said, pulling out the bills. Keep it, he said, chuckling. Consider it compensation for the inconvenience. I can't keep drug money. What drug money? He said with mock innocence. I sell vape pens. Completely legal. These kids are just dramatic. In the tux reappeared. There's two of you? Different hackers. Different Claudius. Other hacker explained. You want your vape pen, you come to me. You want someone to bore you about accounting, you go to him. How do you know I'm an accountant? Lucky guess. He's. The rest of the night became a comedy of errors. Kids would Approach me, I'd point to other Hector. Other Hector's cousin started wearing a name tag that said, the other Claudia. My Claudia made jokes about having the bootleg Hector. Rose's mom, Mytia Elena, pulled me aside during the last dance. I heard there was some confusion with another Hector. Yeah, it's been sorted out. She looked at me seriously. Good. Because if you were doing what he does at my baby's, quinceanera, family or not, I'd end you. Tia, I work at H&R Block. I know, mijo. That's why it's so funny. You can't even jaywalk without having a panic attack. As we were leaving, other Hector caught up to me in the parking lot. Hey, accountant Hector, if you ever want to make some real money. Absolutely not. He laughed. I'm kidding. But seriously, keep the cash. Those kids Learned a valuable lesson.

Have you ever had your abortion protester turn out to be your mom? I was 22, working double shifts at the hospital while finishing nursing school. My boyfriend had left three weeks after I showed him the positive test. I'd made my appointment at the clinic downtown, the only one within 200 miles. I'd researched everything, saved for weeks and made peace with my decision. The morning of my appointment, I pulled into the parking lot to find the usual group of protesters. They were there every Tuesday and Thursday, holding signs with graphic images, shouting at anyone who walked past. I'd seen them before. When I'd come for my initial consultation, I kept my head down, walking quickly toward the entrance. That's when I heard it, a voice that made my blood freeze. Please don't do this. Your baby deserves to live. I turned slowly, praying I was wrong. But there she was, my mother, holding a sign that said Choose Life, standing with a group she'd been volunteering with for the past year. Our eyes met. Her sign dropped to the ground. The other protesters kept shouting, but she stood frozen, her face going pale. I hadn't told her about the pregnancy. We'd barely spoken since I'd moved out at 18. Tired of her controlling every aspect of my life, she'd found her calling in church activism after dad left, throwing herself into causes that made her feel righteous. Becca, she whispered, stepping forward. The other protesters noticed The change looking between us confused. One woman asked if she knew me. Mom just stared, her mouth opening and closing like she couldn't find words. This is why I never told you. I said quiet, because I knew you'd make us about you, about your beliefs, not about what I need. She reached for me, but I stepped back. Sweetheart, let's go somewhere and talk. You don't have to do this. I can help you. We can raise the baby together. Where was the support when I needed help with college tuition? I asked. When I was working three jobs to pay rent. When dad left and you chose your church over your daughter who was begging you to just listen to me for once, the clinic escort approached asking if I was okay. Mom grabbed my arm. Don't let them poison your mind. This is murder, Rebecca. You'll regret this forever. I pulled free. You know what I regret? my mother cares more about a stranger's fetus than her own daughter, daughter's well being. You've been out here every week, haven't you? Screaming at scared women, judging them, never once thinking about their stories. I'm trying to save lives, she protested, tears streaming down her face. No, you're trying to feel important, to feel like you matter. After dad left, but you had a daughter who needed you and you chose this instead. I gestured at the signs, the angry crowd. You chose strangers over me. The Security guard stepped forward asking if there was a problem. Mom looked at him, then at me. Please, she beg. I'm your mother. You're a protester. I corrected. My mother would ask me if I'm okay, if I'm scared, if I need someone to hold my hand. She wouldn't be standing here with a sign condemning me. I want. I walked past her into the clinic. She called after me, but her fellow protesters held her back, reminding her they weren't allowed past the property line. Inside, the nurse asked if I was alright. I nodded, though my hands were shaking. Three hours later when I left, the protesters were gone, but Mom's car was still in the lot. She was sitting in the driver's seat staring at nothing. I knocked on her window. She looked up with red, swollen eyes. I'm okay, I told her. The procedure went fine. She started crying harder. I failed you, didn't I? Long before today, I sat on the curb next to her car. You did, but maybe it's not too.

Thirteen year old niece giggled. Mom says if you disappeared tomorrow, no one would even notice while opening the 850 dollar phone I bought her. All 30 guests laughed except me. I nodded and with two taps I shut down every payment. Credit bills, subscriptions gone for years. I paid Lindsay's rent, covered Dad's gambling debts, handled Mom's credit cards and bought countless expense gift. I was the responsible one who always said yes when they needed money, but never really part of the family, just their walking ATM. The birthday party had 30 relatives gathered around. I driven straight from work to deliver that phone, another expensive gesture to show my love. My niece peeled away the plastic with delicate fingers, but her words cut like glass. Mom says, if you disappeared tomorrow, no one would even notice. The room erupted in laughter. Lindsay smirked from the couch like she'd been waiting for this moment. Mom pretended not to hear from the kitchen, but her shoulders lifted in silent approval. Dad raised his beer and chuckled. Well, she's not wrong. Even Uncle Gary who barely knew me beyond family dinners snorted into his drink. Cousins grinned. Thirty people laughed at my expense while I stood there like the fool I'd always been, the one who paid for everything but mattered to no one. But this time something different happened. Instead of forcing a smile, I felt my phone in my pocket and made two quick taps. Every Bill I Paid every subscription I managed, every credit line I'd set up for them, gone just like that. The voices blurred into distant noise as I slipped out without saying goodbye. No one noticed me leave. The one thing my niece got right, I went home, packed a set, then returned with an old black backpack. While they celebrated, I slipped inside, left it by the stairs and disappeared forever. Inside was proof of everything, receipts, bank statements, payment records showing exactly how much I'd done for people who thought I was nothing. The explosion came the next morning. Dad pounded on my door at dawn, shouting about betrayal and family loyalty. Mom sent desperate texts. How could you do this to your own family? Lindsay called six times, then messaged, you think we can't live without you? Fine. See how long you last without a family. That evening, they broke into my apartment using an old key. Dad stormed in, red faced, mom behind him, both frantic about suddenly cancelled credit cards and unpayable bills. You ungrateful little troublemaker, dad snarled, stepping closer with clenched fists. Try it, I said calmly, still drying my hair from the shower. His hand trembled but didn't move. We both knew he wasn't a fighter, just a bully hiding behind words. The cards don't work, Mom's voice cracked. Lindsay can't pay bills. The mortgage bounced. Everything I paid for is over, I said. You think we need you? Dad laughed bitterly. Seems like you Do since you broke into my apartment just to beg. Dad later invited me to a football game, claiming he wanted to talk like men. When I arrived, he clutched.

What is the longest you've gone without knowing a person's name? 1. I moved into my condo in 2011 and I introduced myself to my one neighbor next door to me but instantly forgot his name. We would see each other in passing for years and I would always just say hi and the casual conversation. I met my wife in 2018 from a long distance relationship. When she finally moved in with me, there was an awkward moment when I introduced her to him. I said this is my fiance and we're getting married next month. He said congratulations and nice to meet you, then walked away. She asked me what his name was and I said I have no clue. Later that day she said his name was Brad. And I was like, oh, he looks like a Brad. And she said he had no clue what my name was either, so no big deal. 2. 2 years. I used to be a club promoter and I had a guy that bought tickets for me for every event he went to. He told me his name when I first met him, but I forgot it soon after he told me. Meeting lots of people makes it hard to remember names, especially when I don't even know if I'll ever see them again. So what's the point of remembering everyone's names after a certain point? I saw him out partying often enough, but it was past the point where I could ask him his name without it being awkward. I had him saved in my phone as Sir Prince Albert since he told me about his piercing so that I'd know who was texting me if we ever texted each other. But I didn't think to add his name since I wasn't sure what it was. So that was no help. Eventually we ended up at a party together and some people walked in and asked, hey, have you seen Phil? After not remembering meeting anyone that night named Phil, I said, no, I don't think there's a Phil here. Then that guy whose name I couldn't remember came up and joined the group and said, I'm right here. Don't worry, these guys are cool. I invited them. At that moment, I finally found out his name and I played it off as, oh, okay, well, if they are your friends, then I guess it's cool if they stay and just went with it. 3. A whole school year I knew their names. I just didn't know which twin was which and they weren't identical. 4. My name is apparently Darren to this nice couple who own a restaurant in my town. My name is not Darren. I've known them for two years. We're even FB friends. They can literally see and read my name. But it's cool. I always wanted to try being a Darren. 5. I've lived in my townhouse for almost five years now and I Don't know the name of the guy who lives directly across from me. I have pretty regular interactions with most of my neighbors, but I've never talked with this one guy beyond just exchanging pleasantries while passing each other. When I moved in and first met him, I immediately forgot his name. I was almost positive he said it was Mike. So I went about four years just assuming that was probably his name, but not quite confident enough to actually call him Mike. Then a few months ago, I was talking to some other neighbors in the parking lot when he walked by and my other neighbors called out, hey. So it was confirmed that this guy's name is not, in fact, Mike. And I was relieved. I hadn't been calling him that for the past 5 years. But I immediately forgot again what his name actually is. So now all I know is that it is something other than Mike. Maybe I'll learn his name by the time I've lived here 10 years. Six, a whole date. Someone fixed us up, but my dude never told me her name, just the address. She wanted me to pick her up. I didn't have the guts to ask her name between the date. She became a longtime GF after that date and we laughed about it. 7. My nickname in college was the mayor and I had people I had known for years coming up to me at my graduation. Saying, I had no idea your name was actually Dan.

Emily Long, the mother who unalived her husband and two children before taking her own life, is now being accused of embezzling $600,000 from her employer. In August, Emily, her husband, and her two children, ages 6 and 8, were found unalived by G U N. Wounds in their home in New Hampshire. Before the unaliving, Emily was the director of operations at a chicken wing restaurant called wing it. The owner of the chains, Derek Fisher, is alleging that Emily stole $660,000 over a two year time period. Now this allegedly occurred between January of 2023 and up until July of this year. He said that they noticed there had been a lot of handwritten checks being deposited in her bank account, according to an August 11th police report. He says that he was going over his locations finances with an accountant when he found several discrepancies stemming from cash deposits that were never actually deposited into the company's account. Sure says that he tried to get answers from Emily before going to the police, but that he was generous with time because he knew that Emily's husband was battling brain cancer. Emily's third child, a toddler, was not injured and is currently staying with the family and Fisher says that anything that's left should go to that child.

I refused to wake up my husband when my parents visited. And kicking them out when they insisted. My husband Tyler, had been working 18 hour days for three weeks straight. Some department at his company completely screwed up and cost them $50 million. So his team had to fix everything. I'm talking coming home at two in the morning, eating cold leftovers, showering and passing out. Some nights I'd find him literally sleeping face first in his dinner plate or passed out on the bathroom floor with the shower still running. Two nights ago, he finally stumbled through the door around midnight with this huge grin on his exhausted face. We did it, he said. Boss gave us the rest of the week off. He ate some leftover pizza, took the world's quickest shower and was snoring before his head hit the pillow. Next morning around 9, I made breakfast but let him sleep. Poor guy looked like a zombie for weeks. Around noon, my parents showed up unannounced. I'm six months pregnant, so they visit sometimes to check on me. We're sitting there having coffee when my mom asks where Tyler is. Since his truck's in the driveway, he's still sleeping, I said. My mom's face went all pinched. It's past noon. That's unacceptable with a pregnant wife. Wake him up. I explained the whole situation. Three weeks of hell. Fifty million dollar crisis. Barely any sleep. My dad just shook his head like Tyler was some lazy bum. I'm not waking him up, I said. He needs to rest. Well, if you won't do it, I will, my mom said, standing up and heading for the stairs. I jumped up and blocked her path. If you can't respect my husband getting proper sleep after three weeks of torture, then you need to leave our house now. Are you kicking us out? My dad asked, all shocked. Yes, get out! They left, all huffy and dramatic. Within an hour, my phone was blowing up, my sister texting me, I'm an ungrateful bitch. My bro

I lost my shit and screamed at my girlfriend to get out of my house after what her stepbrother did. My girlfriend Taylor and I were both 20, and things had been going pretty solid between us for about eight months. She had this stepbrother, Ethan, who was 23. And honestly, the few times I'd met him before, he seemed like a normal dude. Maybe a little too friendly, but nothing that set off major alarm bells. Two weeks ago, Taylor asked if Ethan could come hang out at my place for a few hours. She said he was bringing pizza and beer, and since my parents were visiting my aunt for the weekend, I figured, why not? My little sister Mia is 15, and she was just gonna stay upstairs doing homework anyway. So they showed up around 7. Ethan had this huge grin and two cases of beer. We started drinking and playing video games, just chilling on the couch. Everything was normal for, like, an hour. Taylor was curled up next to me. Ethan was cracking jokes about the game, and I was thinking, this was actually pretty fun. Then Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing, and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs, and I found My sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what happened and she could barely get the words out between sobs. She said Ethan had walked into her room even though her door was only cracked open a little. She thought maybe he was lost looking for the bathroom, so she tried to be polite and tell him it was downstairs.

When did someone's rudeness backfire spectacularly? I've been doing health inspections all day. It's Tuesday. I'm wearing khakis and a polo shirt. But after crawling under kitchen equipment and checking grease traps for six hours, I look pretty rough. I stop at Tony's Italian for dinner. Small family place, decent reviews. I order chicken parm to go and sit at the counter waiting. The kitchen's visible through the pass window, and I can see some serious violations. Cross contamination, improper food temps, expired dairy products. The manager, this guy, Tony junior, keeps eyeing me like I'm trouble. I'm just sitting quietly checking my phone. Hey, he finally says, walking over, you gonna order something or just take up space? I already ordered chicken farm to go. He looks me up and down. When? 10 minutes ago. Your server Maria, took my order. He calls Maria over in rapid Italian. She explains in English that, yes, I ordered and paid already. Tony junior looks annoyed. Well, sit at a table, then. And the counters for paying customers. I am a paying customer, and the tables are all full. He's getting more agitated. Look, buddy, this is a family establishment. We don't need people loitering around looking like they just rolled out of a dumpster. The other customers start looking over. An elderly couple at table 3 seems uncomfortable with his tone. I'm just waiting for my food, man. Yeah, well, wait outside. You're making my customers nervous. I glance around. Nobody. Looks nervous. Except him. Sir, I paid for my meal. I'm waiting inside until it's ready. That's when he really loses it. Listen, pal, I don't care what sob story you got. This isn't a homeless shelter. Take your business somewhere else. He's loud enough now that the whole restaurant is watching. I'm not homeless. I'm just waiting for my chicken parm. Sure you are. Maria, cancel his order and refund his money. I want this guy out of here. Maria looks mortified. Tony, he's been very polite. I don't care. Look at him. Dirty clothes, messy hair. This is exactly the kind of clientele that ruins our reputation. The elderly man at table 3 stands up. Excuse me. There's no need to be rude to this young
